Upon her return to the United States, Jackson recorded for Capitol Records in Dutch as well as Japanese.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=227-233}}\n\nIn the United States, Jackson became more identified with the country genre as the 1960s progressed.{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=203}}<ref name=\"allmusic\"/> Between 1965 and 1967, she hosted her own syndicated country television program titled ''Music Village''.<ref name=\"MV\">{{cite book |last1=Abjorensen |first1=Norman |title=Historical Dictionary of Popular Music |date=2017 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield Publishers |isbn=978-1538102152 |page=257}}</ref> In 1965, ''[[Blues in My Heart (album)|Blues in My Heart]]'', became her first album to reach the ''Billboard'' [[Top Country Albums|country albums]] chart, peaking at number nine.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Blues in My Heart'' chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/wanda-jackson/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=15 July 2021 |archive-date=July 27, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210727230828/https://www.billboard.com/music/Wanda-Jackson/chart-history/CLP/song/831386 |url-status=live }}</ref> In 1966, Jackson had her first American commercial success in several years with the top 20 single \"[[The Box It Came In]]\". It was followed by the number 11 chart hit \"[[Tears Will Be the Chaser for Your Wine]]\".<ref name=\"Whitburn Billboard\"/> The singles were issued on her tenth studio album titled ''[[Reckless Love Affair]]'' (1967).<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Reckless Love Affair'' (LP Liner Notes and Album Information) |journal=[[Capitol Records]] |date=March 1967 |id=ST-2704}}</ref> The album became her third chart entry on the ''Billboard'' country albums list, peaking at number 17.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Reckless Love Affair'' chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/wanda-jackson/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=23 July 2021 |archive-date=July 27, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210727230829/https://www.billboard.com/music/Wanda-Jackson/chart-history/CLP/song/832143 |url-status=live }}</ref> Jackson had eleven more charting ''Billboard'' country singles during the 1960s, including the top 40 songs \"A Girl Don't Have to Drink to Have Fun\", \"Both Sides of the Line\", \"My Baby Walked Right Out on Me\" and \"[[Two Separate Bar Stools]]\". Her 1969 single, \"[[My Big Iron Skillet]]\", reached number 20 on the country chart.<ref name=\"Whitburn Billboard\"/> Her three studio albums, ''[[You'll Always Have My Love]]'' (1967), ''[[Cream of the Crop (Wanda Jackson album)|Cream of the Crop]]'' (1968) and ''[[The Many Moods of Wanda Jackson]]'' (1968) made the ''Billboard'' country LP's list.<ref name=\"Billboard Albums\">{{cite book |last1=Whitburn |first1=Joel |title=Joel Whitburn's Top Country Albums: 1967-1997 |date=1997 |publisher=Record Research Inc. |isbn=0898201241}}</ref>\n\nJackson's country recordings also received attention from music critics and journalists. ''Billboard'' magazine described a 1965 studio album as both \"poetic and tearful\".<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Album Reviews: Country Spotlight |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=January 1966 |volume=78 |issue=4 |page=37 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DykEAAAAMBAJ&q=wanda+jackson+sings+country+songs+billboard&pg=PA37 |access-date=17 July 2021 |archive-date=September 26, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210926124917/https://books.google.com/books?id=DykEAAAAMBAJ&q=wanda+jackson+sings+country+songs+billboard&pg=PA37 |url-status=live }}</ref> Mary A. Bufwack and Robert K. Oermann gave the music a mixed review in their 2003 book: \"Of Wanda's many country hits between 1961 and 1972, none recaptured her rockabilly zing, although several were self-assertive about women's issues.\"{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=203}} Meanwhile, Kurt Wolff described her mid-1960s singles as \"deeply bitter and vengeful\", while also having \"genuine honky-tonk emotion\".{{sfn|Wolff|2000|p=275}} In reviewing a 2006 country compilation album, AllMusic's Thom Jurek found Jackson to be \"a solid, original country singer\".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Jurek |first1=Thom |title=''The Very Best of the Country Years'': Wanda Jackson: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/the-very-best-of-the-country-years-mw0000563115 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=28 July 2021 |archive-date=July 28, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210728034414/https://www.allmusic.com/album/the-very-best-of-the-country-years-mw0000563115 |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nIn 1969, Jackson recorded her first live record in [[Phoenix, Arizona]] titled ''[[Wanda Jackson in Person]]''.<ref name=\"In Person\">{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Wanda Jackson in Person'' (LP Liner Notes and Album Information) |journal=[[Capitol Records]] |date=October 1969 |id=ST-345}}</ref> Following the album, Capitol Records started replacing Ken Nelson with different producers to record Jackson. This included a two-album stint with producer [[George Richey]], which ended in creative differences, according to Jackson.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=252-254}} Richey and Jackson's recordings led to her next major hit called \"[[A Woman Lives for Love]]\" (1970). The single reached number 17 on the ''Billboard'' country songs list.<ref name=\"Whitburn Billboard\"/> In 1971, Jackson was assigned [[Larry Butler (producer)|Larry Butler]] to produce her next studio album titled ''[[I've Gotta Sing]]''.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=252-254}} The project was a commercial success after reaching number 19 on the ''Billboard'' Country LP's list,<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''I've Gotta Sing'' chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/wanda-jackson/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=28 July 2021 |archive-date=July 27, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210727230822/https://www.billboard.com/music/wanda-jackson/chart-history/CLP/song/831811 |url-status=live }}</ref> becoming her first charting album since 1968.<ref name=\"Billboard Albums\"/> It also spawned the single \"[[Fancy Satin Pillows]]\", which became her final top 20 hit on the American country chart.<ref name=\"Whitburn Billboard\"/>\n\n===1972\u20131983: Gospel and christian music transition===\nIn the early 1970s, Jackson and her husband became [[Born again|born-again Christians]].{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=260}} The shift in her personal life prompted Jackson to concentrate more on Gospel music.{{sfn|Wolff|2000|p=276}} \"Wendell and I both felt like God was calling us to stop working in nightclubs and bars in order to dedicate ourselves to the ministry,\" her autobiography recounted.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=262}} Jackson's husband started removing her concerts from the country music night club circuit (which accounted for eighty percent of her income).{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=262}} She also began giving her [[Testimony#Religion|testimony]] on stage, and played various tent show revivals.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=262-264}} In 1972, Capitol released her first Gospel studio project called ''[[Praise the Lord (album)|Praise the Lord]]''. The LP featured vocal harmonies from [[The Oak Ridge Boys]] and included Jackson's first self-penned track.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Praise the Lord'' (LP Liner Notes and Album Information) |journal=[[Capitol Records]] |date=March 1972 |id=ST-11023}}</ref> The record was well received by ''Billboard'' magazine, who called it \"a beautiful spiritual album\".<ref name=\"Billboard\">{{cite magazine |title=Billboard Album Reviews: Country |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=April 8, 1972 |volume=84 |issue=15 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BkUEAAAAMBAJ&q=wanda+jackson+praise+the+lord+billboard+1972&pg=PT73 |access-date=27 July 2021 |archive-date=September 26, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210926124918/https://books.google.com/books?id=BkUEAAAAMBAJ&q=wanda+jackson+praise+the+lord+billboard+1972&pg=PT73 |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nTo fulfill her obligations with Capitol, Jackson continued releasing country LP's.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=269-271}} In 1972, the company released ''[[I Wouldn't Want You Any Other Way]]'', a ten-track collection of traditional country songs.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''I Wouldn't Want You Any Other Way'' (LP Liner Notes and Album Information) |journal=[[Capitol Records]] |date=1972 |id=11096}}</ref> It included the top 40 country hits \"Back Then\" and \"I Already Know (What I'm Getting for My Birthday)\".<ref name=\"Whitburn Billboard\"/> In her next studio sessions, Jackson asked Ken Nelson to record another gospel record, which he did not support. At the same time, [[Word Records]] offered a contract that would allow her the freedom to record more spiritual material. Knowing she was unhappy, Nelson allowed Jackson to accept Word's offer{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=270-271}} and she was released from her Capitol contract.{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=203-204}} Capitol released her last studio album in 1973 titled ''[[Country Keepsakes]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Country Keepsakes'' (LP Liner Notes and Album Information) |journal=[[Capitol Records]] |date=1973 |id=11161}}</ref> The disc peaked at number 43 on the ''Billboard'' Country LP's chart.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Country Keepsakes'' chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/wanda-jackson/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=29 July 2021 |archive-date=July 29, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210729023659/https://www.billboard.com/music/wanda-jackson/chart-history/CLP/song/831507 |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n[[File:Wanda Jackson--1975 (no border).jpg|thumb|left|upright=1.1|Jackson in 1975]]\nJackson's signing with Word allowed her to also record with their imprint label [[Myrrh Records]].<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Word Records for Myrrh: Mod Gospel |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=September 8, 1973 |page=27 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IwkEAAAAMBAJ&q=wanda+jackson+signs+with+word+records&pg=RA1-PA27 |access-date=29 July 2021 |archive-date=September 26, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210926124919/https://books.google.com/books?id=IwkEAAAAMBAJ&q=wanda+jackson+signs+with+word+records&pg=RA1-PA27 |url-status=live }}</ref> In her autobiography, Jackson explained that Word would release her gospel records while Myrrh would release her country records.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=272-274}} In 1973, Word issued her second gospel album titled ''[[Country Gospel (album)|Country Gospel]]''. The project featured covers of the hymn \"[[Farther Along (song)|Farther Along]]\" and [[Kris Kristofferson]]'s Christian tune \"[[Why Me (Kris Kristofferson song)|Why Me, Lord]]\".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Country Gospel'' (LP Liner Notes and Album Information) |journal=[[Word Records]] |date=1973 |id=WST-8614}}</ref> In 1974, Myrrh released the country record ''[[When It's Time to Fall in Love Again]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''When It's Time to Fall in Love Again'' (LP Liner Notes and Album Information) |journal=[[Myrrh Records]] |date=1974 |id=MST-6510}}</ref> Spawned from the album was the single, \"Come on Home (To This Lonely Heart)\". ''Billboard'' described the song as \"a beautiful love song\" that hinted at her Christian \"inner spirits\".<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Billboard's Top Single Picks: Country |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=December 8, 1973 |page=67 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=DwkEAAAAMBAJ&q=wanda+jackson+come+on+home+to+this+lonely+heart+billboard&pg=PA67 |access-date=29 July 2021 |archive-date=September 26, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210926124918/https://books.google.com/books?id=DwkEAAAAMBAJ&q=wanda+jackson+come+on+home+to+this+lonely+heart+billboard&pg=PA67 |url-status=live }}</ref> The single was Jackson's last to chart on the Hot Country Singles survey, peaking at number 98.<ref name=\"Billboard\"/> Jackson later claimed that Word lost interest in her country recordings after being bought out by [[Dot Records]]. She was then left to only record gospel. \"I was stuck, once again, being pigeonholed,\" Jackson commented in her book.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=273-274}}\n\nFor the remainder of the decade, Word and Myrrh released three more studio recordings of Jackson's gospel material: ''[[Now I Have Everything]]'' (1975),<ref name=\"Now I Have Everything\">{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Now I Have Everything'' (LP Information) |journal=[[Myrrh Records]] |date=March 1975 |id=MST-6533}}</ref> ''[[Make Me Like a Child Again]]'' (1976),<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Make Me Like a Child Again'' (LP Information) |journal=[[Myrrh Records]] |date=March 1976 |id=MST-6556}}</ref> and ''[[Closer to Jesus]]'' (1977)<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Closer to Jesus'' (LP Information) |journal=[[Word Records]] |date=1977 |id=WST-8781}}</ref> Reflecting on the LP's in her autobiography, Jackson commented that none of them were \"particularly memorable\" to her. In 1979, her contract with the labels ended.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=274}} In need of a change, the Jackson family temporarily moved to Texas where she became a stay-at-home mother. Yet, the family was unhappy with the move. In 1980, they relocated to Oklahoma City where they built a house and she continued her entertainment career.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=276-279}} The same year, Jackson released a new country disc on the UK-based Deep Sea Music company titled ''[[Good Times (Wanda Jackson album)|Good Times]]''. The album spawned one single, a cover of [[Melba Montgomery]]'s \"[[Don't Let the Good Times Fool You (song)|Don't Let the Good Times Fool You]]\".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Good Times'' (LP Information) |journal=Deep Sea Music |date=1979 |id=DSM-001}}</ref> In 1982, [[K-tel]] released a studio album of re-recordings titled ''[[Let's Have a Party (1982 Wanda Jackson album)|Let's Have a Party]]''.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Let's Have a Party'' (LP Information) |journal=[[K-tel]] |date=1982 |id=NC-549}}</ref> With limited commercial attention to her music, Jackson felt professionally-stuck. \"I wasn't even fifty yet, but I felt like I'd been forced into an early retirement as time had passed me by,\" she recalled in her 2017 book.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=278}}\n\n===1984\u20132006: Rock and roll revival===\nIn the mid-1980s, rockabilly music increased in popularity in Europe, as did rock and roll.<ref name=\"Austin American\">{{cite web |last1=Caldwell |first1=Patrick |title=Birthday bash celebrates rockabilly's 'queen,' Wanda Jackson |url=https://www.austin360.com/article/20120901/ENTERTAINMENT/309019482 |website=[[Austin American-Statesman]] |access-date=5 August 2021 |archive-date=August 5, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210805011631/https://www.austin360.com/article/20120901/ENTERTAINMENT/309019482 |url-status=live }}</ref> Jackson's Capitol rock recordings received interest from European fans and she was soon sought out by overseas promoters.{{sfn|Wolff|2000|p=276}}{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=204}} Jackson and her husband saw the opportunity as a message from God. \"Wendell and I both realized that God was going to use our testimony in places that needed it\", her autobiography explained.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=283}} In 1984, her husband received a phone call from Swedish businessman, Harry Holmes, who was interested in recording her. Jackson then traveled to Scandinavia to record her first album of rock material in two decades.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=280}} In 1984, Tab Records released ''[[Rockabilly Fever]]''. The album was later released in the United States as ''Rock 'N' Roll Away Your Blues''. The project featured covers of rockabilly numbers like \"[[Stupid Cupid]]\" and \"[[It's Only Make Believe]]\".<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Rockabilly Fever'' (LP Information) |journal=Tab Records |date=1984 |id=TAB-LP-8404}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Rock 'N' Roll Away Your Blues'' (LP Information) |journal=Varrick Records |date=1986 |id=VR-025}}</ref> The album received a three-star rating from Allmusic,<ref>{{cite web |title=''Rock 'N' Roll Away Your Blues'': Wanda Jackson: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/rock-roll-away-your-blues-mw0000312703 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=5 August 2021 |archive-date=August 5, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210805011629/https://www.allmusic.com/album/rock-roll-away-your-blues-mw0000312703 |url-status=live }}</ref> while writers Mary Bufwack and Robert Oermann positively described it as \"rockabilly fire\".{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=204}}\n\n[[File:Wanda jackson.JPG|thumb|right|230px|Jackson's rock and roll music saw a revival in Europe where she performed at many festivals, such as the [[Sjock Festival]] in Belgium, 2008.]]\nJackson frequently toured Europe during this period and sang her 1950s rockabilly records. Many of the songs she performed had not been in her regular stage show for years. She recalled having to re-learn the lyrics to songs like \"Mean Mean Man\" after getting hundreds of requests.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=281-283}} As the decade progressed, she found opportunities touring in various European counties, including [[Spain]], [[Switzerland]], [[Hungary]], the [[Czech Republic]] and the [[United Kingdom]].{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=284}} Continued interest in her rock music led to further album releases, including 1988's ''[[Let's Have a Party in Prague]]''. The album was a collaborative studio LP with Czech performer [[Karel Zich]] and was released on the [[Supraphon]] label.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |last2=Zich |first2=Karel |title=''Let's Have a Party in Prague'' (LP Information) |journal=[[Supraphon]] |date=1987 |id=11-0199-1-311}}</ref> She also continued releasing gospel material, such as ''[[Show Me the Way to Calvary]]'' (1981) on the Christian World label<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Show Me the Way to Calvary'' (LP Information) |journal=Christian World |date=1981 |id=CW-5002}}</ref> and ''[[Teach Me to Love]]'' (1984) on Vine Records.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Teach Me to Love'' (Album Information) |journal=Vine Records |date=1984 |id=VI-10682-LP}}</ref> She also issued new collections of country recordings, such as ''[[Classy Country]]'' on Amethyst Records (1988).<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Classy Country'' (Cassette Liner Notes and Album Information) |journal=Amethyst Records |date=1988 |id=AR-8829}}</ref>\n\nIn the 1990s, Jackson was informed of rockabilly's resurgence in the United States by country artist [[Rosie Flores]]. The two visited at Jackson's home where Flores played several rockabilly records and informed her the growing American fan-base. A friendship developed between the two performers{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=284}} and Jackson later appeared on Flores's album ''Rockabilly Filly'' (1995).<ref>{{cite web |last1=Sytsma |first1=Sara |title=''Rockabilly Filly'': Rosie Flores: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/rockabilly-filly-mw0000177263 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=5 August 2021 |archive-date=August 5, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210805015326/https://www.allmusic.com/album/rockabilly-filly-mw0000177263 |url-status=live }}</ref> Following the album's release, the pair embarked on a five-week North American tour. Jackson was surprised to find that her audience was young and the venues were at times uncomfortable: \"It was kind of eye-opening. Even though the rooms were a little frightening, the audiences couldn't have been sweeter,\" she stated.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=287}} In the mid 1990s, Jackson also collaborated with [[The Alligators]] for studio releases on the Success and Elap labels: ''[[Let's Have a Party (1995 Wanda Jackson album)|Let's Have a Party]]'' (1995)<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Let's Have a Party'' (Album Information) |journal=Success Records |date=1993 |id=16239}}</ref> and ''[[The Queen of Rock' a 'Billy]]'' (1997).<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''The Queen of Rockabilly'' (Album Information) |journal=Success Records |date=1997 |id=41645}}</ref>\n\nIn 2001, Jackson played at the Rockabilly Festival in [[Jackson, Tennessee]] alongside The Cadillac Angels.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1474998/rockabilly-festival-on-tap-for-jackson.jhtml|title=Rockabilly Festival on Tap for Jackson|website=Cmt.com|access-date=October 11, 2008|archive-date=February 1, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201194233/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1474998/rockabilly-festival-on-tap-for-jackson.jhtml|url-status=dead}}</ref> In October 2003, [[CMH Records]] released her first American rock album in several decades titled ''[[Heart Trouble (album)|Heart Trouble]]''.<ref name=\"Heart Trouble\">{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Heart Trouble'' (Album Information) |journal=[[CMH Records]] |date=October 14, 2003 |id=CD-8708}}</ref> She recalled in her autobiography that the project was originally intended to be a [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass]] collection. After word spread that Jackson would record an album, several rock musicians contacted the label about joining the production.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=290-291}} Musicians that collaborated on the CD included Rosie Flores, [[The Cramps]] and [[Elvis Costello]].<ref name=\"Heart Trouble\"/> AllMusic's Thom Jurek praised the disc in his review: \"Simply put, this is a rock & roll dream, full of raw, sharp performances, killer songs, and Jackson's irrepressible ability to take even the most innocent song and make it salacious.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Jurek |first1=Thom |title=''Heart Trouble'': Wanda Jackson: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/heart-trouble-mw0000319144 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=5 August 2021 |archive-date=August 5, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210805015326/https://www.allmusic.com/album/heart-trouble-mw0000319144 |url-status=live }}</ref> Charlotte Robinson of [[PopMatters]] called the album a \"triumphant return\" despite the fact that it \"uses the same gimmicks as lesser 'comeback' albums.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Robinson |first1=Charlotte |title=Wanda Jackson: ''Heart Trouble'' |url=https://www.popmatters.com/jacksonwanda-heart-2495952565.html |website=[[PopMatters]] |date=October 2003 |access-date=5 August 2021 |archive-date=August 5, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210805015336/https://www.popmatters.com/jacksonwanda-heart-2495952565.html |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nIn January 2006, [[Goldenlane Records]] issued Jackson's forty-third studio album, titled ''[[I Remember Elvis]]''. The disc was dedicated to Elvis Presley, who she paid tribute to in the liner notes: \"Without the encouragement of Elvis, I may have never recorded rock and roll. So this tribute is just my way of saying thank you to a dear friend.\"<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''I Remember Elvis'' (Album Information) |journal=[[Goldenlane Records]] |date=January 31, 2006 |id=CLP-1568}}</ref> The project received a positive response from Mark Deming of AllMusic, who wrote, \"''I Remember Elvis'' is something short of revelatory, but it is a sincere and loving tribute to an influential artist from someone who learned from him first-hand.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Deming |first1=Mark |title=''I Remember Elvis'': Wanda Jackson: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/i-remember-elvis-mw0000354651 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=5 August 2021 |archive-date=May 2, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210502032813/https://www.allmusic.com/album/i-remember-elvis-mw0000354651 |url-status=live }}</ref> ''[[Slant Magazine]]'' gave the collection a three-star rating and praised Jackson's vocals while noting that the arrangements lacked distinction from Presley's originals.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Keefe |first1=Jonathan |title=Review, Wanda Jackson: ''I Remember Elvis'' |url=https://www.slantmagazine.com/music/wanda-jackson-i-remember-elvis/ |website=[[Slant Magazine]] |date=February 2006 |access-date=5 August 2021 |archive-date=August 5, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210805020915/https://www.slantmagazine.com/music/wanda-jackson-i-remember-elvis/ |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n===2007\u20132021: Collaborations and retirement===\nJackson continued a busy touring schedule in the late 2000's. This included several performances in [[London, England]]<ref>{{cite news |last1=Cartwright |first1=Garth |title='I never kissed a bear!' Presley dated her, McCartney covered her, Costello worships her. As Wanda Jackson hits Britain, Garth Cartwright finds the queen of rockabilly finally getting her due |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2007/jul/16/popandrock2 |website=[[The Guardian]] |date=July 16, 2007 |access-date=11 August 2021 |archive-date=August 11, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210811005519/https://www.theguardian.com/music/2007/jul/16/popandrock2 |url-status=live }}</ref> and a popular gig in [[Santa Barbara, California]].<ref>{{cite web |last1=Comingore |first1=Aly |title=Wanda Jackson at Velvet Jones |url=https://www.independent.com/2007/09/06/wanda-jackson-velvet-jones/ |website=[[Santa Barbara Independent]] |date=September 6, 2007 |access-date=11 August 2021 |archive-date=August 11, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210811005520/https://www.independent.com/2007/09/06/wanda-jackson-velvet-jones/ |url-status=live }}</ref> She also collaborated with Jerry Lee Lewis and [[Linda Gail Lewis]] for performances at the [[London Forum]] during this time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.londonrocknroll.com/|title=London Rock & Roll.com|access-date=October 11, 2008|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150801192449/http://www.londonrocknroll.com/|archive-date=August 1, 2015}}</ref> Following her 2009 induction into the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]],<ref>{{cite web |title=Rockabilly's Wanda Jackson Hits Hall Of Fame |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=102429717 |website=[[NPR]] |access-date=11 August 2021 |archive-date=August 11, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210811005520/https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=102429717 |url-status=live }}</ref> Jackson was approached by rock musician [[Jack White]] to record her next album.<ref name=\"Billboard 2011\">{{cite magazine |last1=Graff |first1=Gar |title=Wanda Jackson 'Wasn't Sure' Jack White Collaboration Would Work on 'Party Ain't Over' |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/473397/wanda-jackson-wasnt-sure-jack-white-collaboration-would-work-on-party-aint-over |access-date=11 August 2021 |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=January 26, 2011 |archive-date=August 11, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210811011021/https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/473397/wanda-jackson-wasnt-sure-jack-white-collaboration-would-work-on-party-aint-over |url-status=live }}</ref> The pair exchanged song ideas virtually and met for the first time in 2010 to record the album.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=301-302}} Jackson did not think she would \"see eye to eye\" with White, who was used to recording \"contemporary rock-style music\".<ref name=\"Billboard 2011\"/> She eventually became more trusting after getting to know him better. \"It was clear that Jack was for me in every way, and I felt honored by the respect he showed me,\" Jackson recalled in her autobiography.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=302}} White had Jackson record several songs he selected, including [[Little Richard]]'s \"[[Rip It Up (Little Richard song)|Rip It Up]]\" and [[Amy Winehouse]]'s \"[[You Know I'm No Good]]\". White also contacted [[Bob Dylan]], who requested she record his original \"[[Thunder on the Mountain]]\". Jackson agreed and cut the tracks, along with several others for the project.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=302-305}}\n\n[[File:Wanda Jackson b\u00e9thune retro 2014 01.JPG|thumb|left|upright|Jackson onstage in 2014. She continued performing until her retirement in 2019.]]\nIn January 2011, her forty-second album was released, titled ''[[The Party Ain't Over]]''. The rock collection was released on Jack White's record label named [[Third Man Records]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''The Party Ain't Over'' (CD Liner Notes and Album Information) |journal=[[Third Man Records]] |date=January 25, 2011 |id=7559797845}}</ref> It became Jackson's first album to chart the [[Billboard 200]] all-genre list, peaking at number 58.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''The Party Ain't Over'' chart history (Billboard 200) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/wanda-jackson/chart-history/tlp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=11 August 2021 |archive-date=August 11, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210811005519/https://www.billboard.com/music/wanda-jackson/chart-history/TLP/song/682086 |url-status=live }}</ref> It also became her first disc to make the ''Billboard'' [[Top Rock Albums]] chart, where it climbed to number 17.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''The Party Ain't Over'' chart history (Rock Albums) |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/wanda-jackson/chart-history/rck/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=11 August 2021 |archive-date=August 11, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210811005519/https://www.billboard.com/music/wanda-jackson/chart-history/RCK/song/682086 |url-status=live }}</ref> The record received a three-star rating from Allmusic's [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] who argued that White's influence overshadowed Jackson's musical image. Erlewine did praise Jackson's vocals and found several tracks that felt like \"they belong to her\".<ref>{{cite web |last1=Erlewine |first1=Stephen Thomas |title=''The Party Ain't Over'': Wanda Jackson: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/the-party-aint-over-mw0002051291 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=11 August 2021 |archive-date=August 11, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210811005519/https://www.allmusic.com/album/the-party-aint-over-mw0002051291 |url-status=live }}</ref> ''[[Rolling Stone]]'''s Jon Dolan gave the album three and half stars and called the track listing \"superb\". \"Jackson\u2019s not content to just remake the greats: Her slaying of Amy Winehouse's 'You Know I\u2019m No Good' is a master class for her wild-child inheritors\", Dolan concluded.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Dolan |first1=Jon |title=The Party Ain't Over |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-album-reviews/the-party-aint-over-85366/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=January 25, 2011 |access-date=11 August 2021 |archive-date=August 11, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210811005519/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-album-reviews/the-party-aint-over-85366/ |url-status=live }}</ref> In her autobiography Jackson recalled making several television appearances to promote the disc. This included performances on the ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'' and ''[[Conan (talk show)|Conan]]''. She also recalled taking the stage for the first time in decades at the Grand Ole Opry.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=304-205}}\n\nJackson did not think she could record an album better than her 2011 release. She was encouraged to return to the studio and collaborate with singer-songwriter [[Justin Townes Earle]].{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=308}} In her autobiography, Jackson reflected that her voice was \"not in top form\" during the album's recording. She blamed a long concert schedule for her vocal quality.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=309}} In October 2012, [[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]] released the project titled ''[[Unfinished Business (Wanda Jackson album)|Unfinished Business]]''. It included liner notes written by [[Stephen King]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Unfinished Business'' (CD Liner Notes and Album Information) |journal=[[Sugar Hill Records (bluegrass label)|Sugar Hill Records]] |date=October 9, 2012 |id=14087}}</ref> The CD peaked at number 61 on the ''Billboard'' Top Country Albums chart in 2012,<ref>{{cite magazine |title=''Unfinished Business'' chart history |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/wanda-jackson/chart-history/clp/ |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=11 August 2021 |archive-date=August 11, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210811012329/https://www.billboard.com/music/wanda-jackson/chart-history/CLP/song/761369 |url-status=live }}</ref> becoming her first disc in 39 years to reach a peak position there.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Morris |first1=Edward |title=Rockabilly Queen Wanda Jackson Announces Retirement, Cancels Shows |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1804438/rockabilly-queen-wanda-jackson-announces-retirement-cancels-shows/ |access-date=11 August 2021 |publisher=[[Country Music Television]] |date=March 27, 2019 |archive-date=August 11, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210811012329/http://www.cmt.com/news/1804438/rockabilly-queen-wanda-jackson-announces-retirement-cancels-shows/ |url-status=dead }}</ref> Mark Deming of AllMusic gave the project a positive response in his review: \"''Unfinished Business'' shows that six decades after her first recordings, that strategy still works, and she can still deliver the goods without a lot of needless fuss.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Deming |first1=Mark |title=''Unfinished Business'': Wanda Jackson: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/unfinished-business-mw0002419234 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=11 August 2021 |archive-date=August 11, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210811012329/https://www.allmusic.com/album/unfinished-business-mw0002419234 |url-status=live }}</ref> Greg Kot of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' found the album was better-suited to Jackson's musical roots compared to previous release, praising her vocal quality and Earle's production.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Kot |first1=Greg |title=Album review: Wanda Jackson, 'Unfinished Business' |url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/ct-xpm-2012-10-08-chi-wanda-jackson-album-review-unfinished-business-reviewed-20121008-story.html |access-date=11 August 2021 |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=October 9, 2012 |archive-date=September 26, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210926124919/https://www.chicagotribune.com/ |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nIn 2017, Jackson's autobiography titled ''Every Night is Saturday Night: A Country Girl's Journey to the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame'' was published.<ref name=\"RS book\">{{cite magazine |last1=McKenna |first1=Brittney |title=Wanda Jackson Unveils Autobiography 'Every Night Is Saturday Night' |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/wanda-jackson-unveils-autobiography-every-night-is-saturday-night-195943/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |access-date=28 August 2021 |archive-date=August 28, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210828185538/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/wanda-jackson-unveils-autobiography-every-night-is-saturday-night-195943/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Co-written by Jackson and Scott Bomar, it was published by [[BMG Music]] and featured a foreword by Elvis Costello. According to an interview, Jackson had attempted an autobiography but found the writing \"didn't come out well\". Working with Bomar made Jackson feel more comfortable with writing a book.<ref name=\"Gazette\">{{cite news |last1=Luschen |first1=Ben |title=Rockabilly Queen Wanda Jackson readies her new autobiography Every Night Is Saturday Night |url=https://www.okgazette.com/oklahoma/rockabilly-queen-wanda-jackson-readies-her-new-autobiography-every-night-is-saturday-night/Content?oid=2993656 |access-date=28 August 2021 |publisher=[[Oklahoma Gazette]] |date=November 8, 2017 |archive-date=August 28, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210828160311/https://www.okgazette.com/oklahoma/rockabilly-queen-wanda-jackson-readies-her-new-autobiography-every-night-is-saturday-night/Content?oid=2993656 |url-status=live }}</ref> The launch was honored by a party, signing and performance at the [[Grammy Museum at L.A. Live|Grammy Museum]].\n\nJackson played a handful of 2018 shows before announcing her retirement in March 2019.<ref name=\"Rolling Stone 2019\">{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/wanda-jackson-health-retirement-touring-815914/|title=Wanda Jackson on Why She Had to Retire From Touring|first1=Jonathan|last1=Bernstein|date=April 1, 2019|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=11 August 2021|archive-date=April 2, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190402154759/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/wanda-jackson-health-retirement-touring-815914/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/wanda-jackson-rockabilly-retires-813853/|title=Wanda Jackson, 'Queen of Rockabilly,' Retires From Performing|first1=Ryan|last1=Reed|date=March 27, 2019|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|access-date=April 20, 2019|archive-date=March 28, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190328145035/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/wanda-jackson-rockabilly-retires-813853/|url-status=live}}</ref> She told ''Rolling Stone'' that a previously undisclosed stroke was partially to blame, along with additional \"health and safety concerns\".<ref name=\"Rolling Stone 2019\"/> In August 2021, [[Big Machine Records]] and [[Blackheart Records]] issued her next studio record titled ''[[Encore (2021 Wanda Jackson album)|Encore]]''. The disc was produced by [[Joan Jett]]. Jett is featured performing on the record, along with [[Elle King]] and [[Angaleena Presley]].<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Jackson |first1=Wanda |title=''Encore'' (CD Liner Notes and Album Information) |journal=Blackheart Records/Big Machine Records |date=August 23, 2021 |id=3006532}}</ref> Jackson announced that the project would be her last album.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Freeman |first1=Jon |title=Wanda Jackson Announces Final Album 'Encore' With Joan Jett |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/wanda-jackson-announces-new-album-encore-1190194/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |access-date=24 November 2021}}</ref> ''Encore'' featured songs co-written by Nashville songwriters like [[Will Hoge]] and [[Lori McKenna]].<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Bernstein |first1=Jonathan |title=Wanda Jackson Says Farewell With One Final Album |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/wanda-jackson-retires-final-album-encore-1215713/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |access-date=24 November 2021}}</ref> It received a positive review from Mark Deming of AllMusic who gave it 3.5 stars: \"Clocking in at a very 1950s 25 minutes, ''Encore'' doesn't feel like a major event and it doesn't add a great deal to the Wanda Jackson story, but it's a welcome reminder that the first truly great female rocker is still among us and hasn't surrendered to time,\" he concluded.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Deming |first1=Mark |title=''Encore'': Wanda Jackson: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/encore-mw0003554976 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=24 November 2021}}</ref> ''[[American Songwriter]]'' commented that Jackson \"sets the standard, and even in her seventh decade of making music, that confidence and control remain readily apparent.\"<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Zimmerman |first1=Lee |title=Review: Wanda Jackson's Remarkable ''Encore'' |journal=[[American Songwriter]] |date=August 2021 |url=https://americansongwriter.com/review-wanda-jacksons-remarkable-encore/ |access-date=27 November 2021}}</ref>\n\n==Artistry==\n===Musical styles and voice===\nJackson's musical style includes rockabilly, country and gospel music.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=200-204}} In her early career, she was known for releasing country and rock records simultaneously.<ref name=\"Essential Songs\">{{cite magazine |last1=Betts |first1=Stephen L. |title=Wanda Jackson: 10 Essential Songs |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/feature/wanda-jackson-essential-songs-rockabilly-815314/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |access-date=25 August 2021 |archive-date=August 25, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210825010644/https://www.rollingstone.com/feature/wanda-jackson-essential-songs-rockabilly-815314/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Music writers and critics have analyzed the reasoning behind this decision. Critic Bruce Eder explained that \"she spent years walking a tightrope between traditional country and rock & roll, just trying to carve out a niche for herself and earn a living\".<ref name=\"Queen of Rockabilly\">{{cite web |last1=Eder |first1=Bruce |title=''Queen of Rockabilly'': Wanda Jackson: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/queen-of-rockabilly-mw0000618189 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=25 August 2021 |archive-date=July 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210714034504/https://www.allmusic.com/album/queen-of-rockabilly-mw0000618189 |url-status=live }}</ref> Author Kurt Wolff wrote that Jackson released both genres simultaneously because she \"never [felt] the need to hide one set of songs from fans of the other.\"{{sfn|Wolff|2000|p=275}} Critic William Ruhlmann theorized that Jackson \"was encouraged to straddle musical genres\" due to her record label's worries that rock would decline in popularity.<ref name=\"debut album\"/>\n[[File:WandaJacksonopSjock.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Jackson in concert, 2008.]]\n\nHer characteristic vocal growl has also been a subject of discussion among writers, critics and historians.<ref name=\"The Independent\">{{cite news |last1=Farber |first1=Jim |title='Elvis saw a feistiness in me': How rockabilly queen Wanda Jackson became one of the boldest artists around |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/wanda-jackson-elvis-presley-encore-b1904159.html |access-date=25 August 2021 |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=August 17, 2021 |archive-date=August 25, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210825005710/https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/wanda-jackson-elvis-presley-encore-b1904159.html |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=\"NPR 2\">{{cite web |last1=Sherman |first1=Maria |title=Forebears: Wanda Jackson, The Queen Of Rockabilly |url=https://www.npr.org/2017/08/08/542186514/forebears-wanda-jackson-the-queen-of-rockabilly |website=[[NPR]] |access-date=25 August 2021 |archive-date=August 25, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210825005710/https://www.npr.org/2017/08/08/542186514/forebears-wanda-jackson-the-queen-of-rockabilly |url-status=live }}</ref> Mary A. Bufwack and Robert K. Oermann stated that Jackson's vocal growl \"captured the elemental, low-class wildness of this music [rock and roll] better than any female of her day.\"{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=204}} [[NPR]]'s Maria Sherman claimed that Jackson's snarl changed the way audiences view female singers and performers.<ref name=\"NPR 2\"/> Stephen L. Betts of ''Rolling Stone'' commented that Jackson's vocal snarl gave her a \"one-of-a-kind voice like spring-loaded dynamite wrapped in sandpaper.\"<ref name=\"Essential Songs\"/> Jackson's singing growl led to one journalist dubbing her as \"a really sweet lady \u2013 with a nasty voice.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Burns |first1=Ken |title=Country Music: Wanda Jackson Biography |url=https://www.pbs.org/kenburns/country-music/wanda-jackson-biography/ |website=[[PBS]] |access-date=25 August 2021 |archive-date=July 9, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210709184803/https://www.pbs.org/kenburns/country-music/wanda-jackson-biography/ |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=\"The Guardian 2\">{{cite news |last1=Petridis |first1=Alexis |title='I couldn't be tied down!' Wanda Jackson, rockabilly's raucous queen |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2021/aug/19/i-couldnt-be-tied-down-wanda-jackson-rockabillys-raucous-queen |access-date=25 August 2021 |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |archive-date=August 25, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210825010425/https://www.theguardian.com/music/2021/aug/19/i-couldnt-be-tied-down-wanda-jackson-rockabillys-raucous-queen |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2023, ''Rolling Stone'' ranked Jackson at number 149 on its list of the 200 Greatest Singers of All Time.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=The 200 Greatest Singers of All Time|magazine=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=1 January 2023|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-lists/best-singers-all-time-1234642307/wanda-jackson-5-1234642911/|access-date=6 April 2023}}</ref>\n\nJackson is also known for being able to [[yodel]]. Several selections in her catalog feature yodeling, including 1969's \"[[Cowboy Yodel Song|Cowboy Yodel]]\"<ref name=\"Allmusic\">{{cite web |title=''Wanda Jackson in Person'': Wanda Jackson: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/wanda-jackson-in-person-live-mw0000971599 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=27 July 2021 |archive-date=July 27, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210727015736/https://www.allmusic.com/album/wanda-jackson-in-person-live-mw0000971599 |url-status=live }}</ref> and 1975's \"Jesus Put a Yodel in My Soul\".<ref name=\"Now I Have Everything\"/> \"I always yodelled. People just loved yodelling,\" she told the [[BBC]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Connolly |first1=Kevin |title=In search of a mystery yodeller |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-22596063 |access-date=6 September 2021 |work=[[BBC]] |date=May 21, 2013 |archive-date=September 6, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210906225745/https://www.bbc.com/news/magazine-22596063 |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n===Performance style and image===\nJackson's choice of stage wear and movement on stage has also been a subject of discussion.<ref name=\"NPR 2\"/><ref name=\"The Guardian 2\"/> Unlike other female country performers, Jackson chose to dress in gold [[Lam\u00e9 (fabric)|lam\u00e9]] outfits and sequined dresses, most of which were designed by her mother.{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=200-204}} \"I was the first one to put some glamour in the country music,\" she explained to the [[Rockabilly Hall of Fame]].<ref name=\"Rockabilly Hall of Fame\">{{cite web |title=Wanda Turns 70: Still Rockin' |url=http://www.rockabillyhall.com/wandajackson.html |website=[[Rockabilly Hall of Fame]] |access-date=25 August 2021 |archive-date=February 10, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210210212342/http://www.rockabillyhall.com/WandaJackson.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Mary A. Bufwack and Robert K. Oermann added that Jackson's outfits demonstrated \"fire, energy, and uninhibited nerve that doubtless shocked conservatives\".{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=201}} The way Jackson moved on stage has also been seen as uncharacteristic of other female performers.{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=201}}<ref name=\"The Guardian 2\"/> Bobby Moore added that Jackson's live shows embedded \"upbeat songs\" and \"high-energy\" that \"compelled audience members to party like they don't have to work the next day.\" In the same interview, she explained her reasoning for putting on a high-energy performance show: \"I feel like it's my job to see that people have a good time when they come out to a concert.\"<ref>{{cite web |last1=Moore |first1=Bobby |title=Country Legend Wanda Jackson Talks Legendary Career |url=https://www.wideopencountry.com/country-legend-wanda-jackson-talks-autobiography/ |website=Wide Open Country |date=September 22, 2017 |access-date=25 August 2021 |archive-date=August 25, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210825014034/https://www.wideopencountry.com/country-legend-wanda-jackson-talks-autobiography/ |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\n===Influence===\nJackson has been referred to as \"[[Honorific nicknames in popular music|The Queen of Rockabilly]]\" due to her being one of the early female performers in the rock genre.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Jurgensen |first1=John |title=Wanda Jackson Returns, with Help from Jack White |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704590704576092203579810560 |access-date=29 August 2021 |agency=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |archive-date=August 29, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210829052217/https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704590704576092203579810560 |url-status=live }}</ref> She has also been considered among the first women to have a life-long career in country music.{{sfn|Wolff|2000|p=275}} Her career has influenced a series of performers in both the country and rock fields. [[Pam Tillis]] is among several country artists who regard Jackson as an influence.<ref name=\"Reaching\">{{cite news |title=Reaching Us |url=https://www.registerguard.com/article/20120413/LIFESTYLE/304139975 |access-date=26 August 2021 |publisher=[[The Register-Guard]] |date=April 13, 2012 |archive-date=August 26, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210826011745/https://www.registerguard.com/article/20120413/LIFESTYLE/304139975 |url-status=live }}</ref> To honor her, Tillis included Jackson on her 1995 [[The Nashville Network|TNN]] concert series hosted at the [[Ryman Auditorium]].<ref>{{cite news |last1=Moore |first1=Scott |title=TILLIS'S CRAZY LIFE INCLUDES TNN SERIES |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/tv/1995/04/09/tilliss-crazy-life-includes-tnn-series/7ace1023-77ec-4a97-9a8f-b766c2f3d6d2/ |access-date=26 August 2021 |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=April 9, 1995 |archive-date=September 26, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210926124933/https://www.washingtonpost.com/archive/lifestyle/tv/1995/04/09/tilliss-crazy-life-includes-tnn-series/7ace1023-77ec-4a97-9a8f-b766c2f3d6d2/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Rosie Flores has also cited Jackson as an influence on her music and career.{{sfn|Wolff|2000|p=276}}<ref name=\"Reaching\"/> Flores spoke of how Jackson influenced her career in a 2012 interview with the ''Chicago Tribune'': \"The main thing I learned was that the older you get, the music you do and the way you put it out doesn't change. You don't have to slow down. You can keep rocking. There is no age when it comes to rock 'n' roll.\"<ref>{{cite news |last1=Dickinson |first1=Chrissie |title=Rosie Flores is, as she ever was, on fire |url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/entertainment/ct-xpm-2012-11-01-ct-ott-1102-rosie-flores-20121101-story.html |access-date=26 August 2021 |newspaper=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=November 1, 2012 |archive-date=September 26, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210926124919/https://www.chicagotribune.com/ |url-status=live }}</ref> [[Jann Browne]] has also cited Jackson as a musical inspiration.{{sfn|Wolff|2000|p=276}}<ref name=\"Reaching\"/> She included Jackson on her 1990 studio album titled ''[[Tell Me Why (Jann Browne album)|Tell Me Why]]''.<ref>{{cite web |last1=McCall |first1=Michael |title=''Tell Me Why'': Jann Browne: Songs, reviews, credits |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/tell-me-why-mw0000207819 |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=26 August 2021 |archive-date=August 26, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210826011746/https://www.allmusic.com/album/tell-me-why-mw0000207819 |url-status=live }}</ref> [[Miranda Lambert]] also found Jackson to be an influence on her career: \"Here was the woman who in so many ways, changed the way audiences and record labels viewed female artists. She literally helped to pave the way for me to do what I love each and every day.\"<ref name=\"Oklahoma HOF\">{{cite web |title=Jackson, Wanda |url=https://oklahomahof.com/member-archives/j/jackson-wanda-2014 |website=[[Oklahoma Hall of Fame]] |access-date=26 August 2021 |archive-date=August 26, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210826011747/https://oklahomahof.com/member-archives/j/jackson-wanda-2014 |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nIn rock music, several artists have also named Jackson an artistic influence. [[Bruce Springsteen]] and Elvis Costello paid tribute to Jackson in her 2008 documentary centered on her life and career.<ref name=\"Smithsonian\">{{cite magazine |last1=Fletcher |first1=Kenneth R. |title=Q and A: Wanda Jackson |journal=[[Smithsonian Magazine]] |date=November 2008 |url=https://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/q-and-a-wanda-jackson-82972754/ |access-date=26 August 2021 |archive-date=May 14, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210514193323/https://www.smithsonianmag.com/arts-culture/q-and-a-wanda-jackson-82972754/ |url-status=live }}</ref> [[Cyndi Lauper]] cited her as one of the earliest influences on her career, recording \"[[Funnel of Love]]\" for her 2016 album ''[[Detour (Cyndi Lauper album)|Detour]]''. \"I think for country you look at [[Patsy Cline]] or [[Loretta Lynn]] who played a guitar, or sang the songs she wrote, and [[Dolly Parton]]. But Wanda Jackson was a rocker, and so, of course, I was going to listen and learn from her because I was a rocker and that's what we did.\"<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Betts |first1=Stephen L. |title=See Cyndi Lauper Channel Wanda Jackson on 'Seth Meyers' |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/see-cyndi-lauper-channel-wanda-jackson-on-seth-meyers-85188/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |access-date=26 August 2021 |archive-date=August 26, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210826014216/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/see-cyndi-lauper-channel-wanda-jackson-on-seth-meyers-85188/ |url-status=live }}</ref> [[Adele (singer)|Adele]] explained that a \"greatest hits\" package by Jackson helped influence her 2008 studio album, ''[[19 (Adele album)|19]]''.<ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Eliscu |first1=Jenny |title=In the Studio: Adele Goes Country on Fall Disc |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/in-the-studio-adele-goes-country-on-fall-disc-177083/ |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |access-date=26 August 2021 |archive-date=August 26, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210826014218/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/in-the-studio-adele-goes-country-on-fall-disc-177083/ |url-status=live }}</ref> Elle King also named Jackson as an influence on her music in 2016.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Stephens |first1=Samantha |title=Wanda Jackson and Elle King Take on \"Riot in Cell Block #9\" |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1771732/wanda-jackson-and-elle-king-take-on-riot-in-cell-block-9/ |access-date=26 August 2021 |agency=[[Country Music Television]] |date=October 5, 2016 |archive-date=August 26, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210826014217/http://www.cmt.com/news/1771732/wanda-jackson-and-elle-king-take-on-riot-in-cell-block-9/ |url-status=dead }}</ref>\n\n==Recognition and legacy==\nJackson was twice nominated for [[Grammy Awards]]. Her 1964 album, ''Two Sides of Wanda'', was nominated for [[Best Female Country Vocal Performance]]. In 1970, \"A Woman Lives for Love\" was nominated for the same.<ref name=\"Grammys\">{{cite web |title=Wanda Jackson: Artist |url=https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/wanda-jackson/3462 |website=[[Grammy Awards]] |access-date=July 14, 2021 |archive-date=December 16, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191216064837/https://www.grammy.com/grammys/artists/wanda-jackson |url-status=live }}</ref> Her recording of \"[[Let's Have a Party]]\" was inducted into the [[Grammy Hall of Fame]] in 2024.<ref>https://www.grammy.com/news/grammy-hall-fame-2024-recordings-inducted-lauryn-hill-guns-n-roses {{Bare URL inline|date=August 2024}}</ref>\n\nJackson's work got more recognition several decades later when she received the [[National Heritage Fellowship|Fellowship Award]] from the [[National Endowment for the Arts]]. She became the first female country and rock performer to receive the accolade.<ref>{{cite news |title=Singer Wanda Jackson receives national award |url=https://www.oklahoman.com/article/2913763/singer-wanda-jackson-receives-national-award |access-date=28 August 2021 |publisher=[[The Oklahoman]] |date=September 30, 2005 |archive-date=August 28, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210828160310/https://www.oklahoman.com/article/2913763/singer-wanda-jackson-receives-national-award |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nDuring this period, various rock musicians began advocating for Jackson to be inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. In 2005, Elvis Costello wrote a letter to the organization about why she should be inducted. Cyndi Lauper and Bruce Springsteen also advocated for her.<ref name=\"Gazette\"/><ref>{{cite news |last1=Adams |first1=Sam |title=A rockabilly legend pushes back |url=https://www.inquirer.com/philly/entertainment/20110218_A_rockabilly_legend_pushes_back.html |access-date=28 August 2021 |work=[[The Philadelphia Inquirer]] |date=February 18, 2011 |archive-date=August 28, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210828161815/https://www.inquirer.com/philly/entertainment/20110218_A_rockabilly_legend_pushes_back.html |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2005, she was nominated by the organization.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1490946/twitty-jackson-nominated-for-rock-hall.jhtml|title=Twitty, Jackson Nominated for Rock Hall|website=Cmt.com|access-date=October 11, 2008|archive-date=October 16, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121016210530/http://www.cmt.com/news/news-in-brief/1490946/twitty-jackson-nominated-for-rock-hall.jhtml|url-status=dead}}</ref> In 2009, Jackson was officially inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame under the category \"Early Influence\". She was presented with the induction by singer-songwriter [[Rosanne Cash]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Wanda Jackson: Rock & Roll Hall of Fame |url=https://www.rockhall.com/inductees/wanda-jackson |website=[[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] |access-date=28 August 2021 |archive-date=August 16, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210816182246/https://www.rockhall.com/inductees/wanda-jackson |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nJackson was also inducted into the Rockabilly Hall of Fame,<ref name=\"Rockabilly Hall of Fame\"/> the Iowa Rock and Roll Hall of Fame,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.iowarocknroll.com/inductees?query=&year=2013&category=35&sortBy=0 |title=Iowa Rock n Roll Music Association \u2013 Inductee List |website=Iowarocknroll.com |access-date=July 1, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150701225634/https://www.iowarocknroll.com/inductees?query=&year=2013&category=35&sortBy=0 |archive-date=July 1, 2015 |url-status=dead }}</ref> the [[Oklahoma Hall of Fame]]<ref name=\"Oklahoma HOF\"/> and the Oklahoma Country Music Hall of Fame.<ref name=\"OK Senate\">{{cite web |title=Senate Honors Queen of Rockabilly Wanda Jackson |url=https://oksenate.gov/press-releases/senate-honors-queen-rockabilly-wanda-jackson |website=[[Oklahoma Senate]] |date=February 10, 2009 |access-date=28 August 2021 |archive-date=August 28, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210828160312/https://oksenate.gov/press-releases/senate-honors-queen-rockabilly-wanda-jackson |url-status=live }}</ref><ref name=\"Rockabilly Hall of Fame\"/> On an international level, she has been inducted into the International Gospel Hall of Fame<ref name=\"Phoenix\">{{cite news |last1=D'Andrea |first1=Nick |title=Wanda Jackson |url=https://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/music/wanda-jackson-6402872 |access-date=28 August 2021 |publisher=[[Phoenix New Times]] |date=January 18, 2007 |archive-date=August 28, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210828160311/https://www.phoenixnewtimes.com/music/wanda-jackson-6402872 |url-status=live }}</ref> and the German Country Music Hall of Fame.<ref name=\"Phoenix\"/><ref name=\"OK Senate\"/>\n\nIn 2009, Oklahoma City named an alley for Jackson in the Bricktown entertainment district.<ref>{{cite news |title=Wanda Jackson gets her \"Way\" in Oklahoma City |url=https://www.oklahoman.com/article/3405198/wanda-jackson-gets-her-way-in-oklahoma-city |access-date=28 August 2021 |publisher=[[Oklahoman]] |date=September 30, 2009 |archive-date=August 28, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210828160311/https://www.oklahoman.com/article/3405198/wanda-jackson-gets-her-way-in-oklahoma-city |url-status=live }}</ref> Jackson's hometown of Maud also named one of their streets after her.<ref>{{cite web |title=Oklahoma Music Trail: Wanda Jackson Itinerary |url=https://www.travelok.com/music-trail/itineraries/wanda-jackson-itinerary |website=Travel Oklahoma |access-date=28 August 2021 |archive-date=August 28, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210828160321/https://www.travelok.com/music-trail/itineraries/wanda-jackson-itinerary |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2010, she and [[John Mellencamp]] were recipients of the Lifetime Achievement award from the [[Americana Music Honors & Awards|Americana Music Honors]].<ref>{{cite news |title=John Mellencamp, Wanda Jackson Will Receive Americana Lifetime Achievement Awards |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1645289/john-mellencamp-wanda-jackson-will-receive-americana-lifetime-achievement-awards/ |access-date=28 August 2021 |publisher=[[Country Music Television]] |date=August 6, 2010 |archive-date=August 28, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210828160312/http://www.cmt.com/news/1645289/john-mellencamp-wanda-jackson-will-receive-americana-lifetime-achievement-awards/ |url-status=dead }}</ref> In 2016, she was the recipient of the \"Founder of the Sound\" award at the Ameripolitan Music Awards.<ref>{{cite web |title=Ameripolitan Music Awards |url=https://www.ameripolitan.com/copy-of-about |website=Ameripolitan Music Awards |access-date=28 August 2021 |archive-date=August 28, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210828160311/https://www.ameripolitan.com/copy-of-about |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nIn 2002, she was included on [[Country Music Television|CMT]]'s televised special of the \"40 Great Women in Country Music\".<ref>{{cite news |title=''40 Greatest Women Announced'' |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1457238/40-greatest-women-announced/ |access-date=28 August 2021 |publisher=[[Country Music Television]] |date=August 28, 2002 |archive-date=March 10, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210310005543/http://www.cmt.com/news/1457238/40-greatest-women-announced/ |url-status=dead }}</ref> In 2006 Alfred Publishing acknowledged her influence on young musicians by publishing ''The Best of Wanda Jackson: Let's Have a Party'', a songbook with music and lyrics to thirteen songs associated with Jackson.<ref>{{cite book |last=Jackson |first=Wanda |date=2006 |title=The Best of Wanda Jackson: Let's Have a Party |location=Van Nuys, California |publisher=Alfred Music |id=25979 |isbn=9780739042793 |oclc=76907141}}</ref> In 2008, the [[Smithsonian Channel]] released a documentary focused on Jackson's career titled ''The Sweet Lady with the Nasty Voice''.<ref name=\"Smithsonian\"/> In 2019, [[Ken Burns]] profiled her in his televised documentary titled ''[[Country Music (miniseries)|Country Music]]''.<ref name=\"PBS\"/>\n\n==Personal life==\n===Relationships and family===\n[[File:Elvis Presley.jpg|thumb|right|180px|In the mid 1950s, Jackson dated fellow rock and roll artist [[Elvis Presley]].]]\nAfter Jackson spent time touring with Elvis Presley, the pair's relationship became romantic in 1955.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/><ref>{{cite magazine |last1=Sullivan |first1=James |title=Wanda Jackson Remembers Elvis |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=December 9, 2005 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/wanda-jackson-remembers-elvis-96708/ |access-date=12 September 2021 |archive-date=September 13, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210913000346/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/wanda-jackson-remembers-elvis-96708/ |url-status=live }}</ref> He asked her to make the relationship official by giving Jackson a small diamond ring that she wore on a necklace.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=103}} In her autobiography, she explained that Presley \"won my heart as I was just beginning to understand what it really meant to embrace my femininity and express myself as a young woman.\"{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=85}} According to Jackson, the pair's relationship ended in 1956 once Presley began appearing in films and [[Colonel Tom Parker]] took control of his career.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=119-121}}\n\nIn her teen years, Jackson befriended aspiring country performer [[Norma Jean (singer)|Norma Jean]]. The two often appeared on the ''Ozark Jubilee'' television show and socialized frequently. Norma Jean began dating local resident, Wendell Goodman, and Jackson sometimes joined them on dates.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=202-204}} In 1961, Norma Jean accepted an offer to become a cast member of ''[[The Porter Wagoner Show]]'' in Nashville and ended her relationship with Goodman. Jackson and Goodman started dating shortly after their breakup. In her 2017 book, she recalled that she fell in love with him prior to their dating: \"When they [Norma Jean and Goodman] had first come into the house and I saw Wendell, that was it. It was love at first sight.\"{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=205-206}} The couple married in 1961.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=202}} Goodman had begun a career in computers with IBM, but left the position to become his wife's full-time business manager.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Wanda Jackson & Pam Tillis: Rockin' the Country: Women at the Fore |journal=Elmore Magazine |date=May 1, 2007 |url=https://www.elmoremagazine.com/2007/05/influences/wanda-jackson-pam-tillis |access-date=30 August 2021 |archive-date=August 30, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210830010205/https://www.elmoremagazine.com/2007/05/influences/wanda-jackson-pam-tillis |url-status=live }}</ref> He later oversaw and managed his wife's company named Wanda Jackson Enterprises. In 2017, Goodman died at the age of 81.<ref>{{cite news |title=Wendell Goodman, husband and manager of Oklahoma music legend Wanda Jackson, died Sunday |url=https://www.oklahoman.com/article/5550043/wendell-goodman-husband-and-manager-of-oklahoma-music-legend-wanda-jackson-died-sunday |access-date=30 August 2021 |work=[[The Oklahoman]] |date=May 22, 2017 |archive-date=August 30, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210830010204/https://www.oklahoman.com/article/5550043/wendell-goodman-husband-and-manager-of-oklahoma-music-legend-wanda-jackson-died-sunday |url-status=live }}</ref>\n\nThe couple had two children together.{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=202}} Their daughter, Gina, was born in 1962{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=218}} while their son, Greg, was born in 1964.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=220}} Because Jackson's husband traveled with her, their children were kept home and raised by nannies. Jackson's parents also kept the children on weekends. \"I knew it wasn't a normal childhood for them, and I've always carried a little guilt about that,\" she recalled in 2017.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=220-222}}\n\n===Personal challenges and spirituality===\n{{quote box\n| quote = \"I had a lot to learn, but God was teaching me. We were surrounded by some of the greatest people who came alongside us and shepherded us as we grew in our faith. I felt like, at the age of thirty-three, I was just learning what it really meant to live life to the fullest. He saved our marriage, too, as Wendell and I came together in pursuit of spiritual morality. Our priorities were realigned and we were both filled with an indescribable sense of peace.\"\n| source = &nbsp;\u2014 Jackson, in her autobiography{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=262}}\n| width = 25%\n| align = right\n}}\nBy 1971, Jackson had become increasingly unhappy in her professional and personal life. \"I had everything that a person could need or want. But I still couldn't shake that dull but persistent sense of emptiness inside,\" she later explained.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=258}} She and her husband had also developed a problem with alcohol. Their problems with drinking led Goodman to become physically and verbally abusive with Jackson.{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=202}} Upon returning from a show, Jackson recalled going to church with her family and having a life-altering experience. \"After we got up off our knees, everything was different,\" she stated in her autobiography.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=262}} The couple found solace in Christianity and dedicated their personal lives to spirituality in 1971.<ref name=\"allmusic\"/>{{sfn|Oermann|Bufwack|2003|p=202}} They were later baptized, and the couple went on to state that faith saved their marriage.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=262}}\n\nThe couple's belief in their faith would lead them to working with [[Evangelism|Evangelist]]s in [[Dallas, Texas]] during the late 1970s. Her husband set up an office building in the city where that offered resources to various ministries in the local area.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=274-278}} As Jackson's rockabilly music revived in the 1980s, the couple decided to invest less professional time with Christianity.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Morris |first1=Edward |title=Country Legends We Love: Wanda Jackson |url=http://www.cmt.com/news/1821240/country-legends-we-love-wanda-jackson/ |website=[[Country Music Television]] |access-date=30 August 2021 |archive-date=July 13, 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210713035305/http://www.cmt.com/news/1821240/country-legends-we-love-wanda-jackson/ |url-status=dead }}</ref> \"It was hard to feel right about singing in bars again, but God confirmed in my spirit, time and time again, that that's where He wanted me and that's where I could be most effective,\" she explained in her autobiography.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=283}}\n\n===Health problems===\nIn the 2010s, Jackson developed [[pneumonia]] and was hospitalized for a week.<ref name=\"Rolling Stone 2019\"/> A knee replacement became infected with [[Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus|MRSA]] and she fell several times in her Oklahoma house, damaging her shoulder.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=309}} In 2017, her internal bleeding was treated at a hospital in [[Tijuana, Mexico]] that focused on nutritional and medical therapy.{{sfn|Bomar|Jackson|2017|p=311}} A 2018 stroke led her to retire.<ref name=\"Rolling Stone 2019\"/> She said it would have impaired her more if her daughter had brought her to the hospital later. \"I was so fortunate\", she told ''[[The Independent]]'' in 2021.<ref name=\"The Independent\"/>\n\n==Discography==\n{{main|Wanda Jackson albums discography|Wanda Jackson singles discography}}\n\n;Studio albums\n{{div col}}\n* ''[[Wanda Jackson (album)|Wanda Jackson]]'' Cash\n| birth_date         = {{birth date|1932|2|26|mf=y}}\n| birth_place        = [[Kingsland, Arkansas]], U.S.\n| death_date         = {{death date and age|2003|9|12|1932|2|26|mf=y}}\n| death_place        = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| resting_place      = [[Hendersonville Memory Gardens]]\n| occupation         = {{hlist|Singer|songwriter|musician|actor<!-- Discuss on talk page before changing. -->}}\n| years_active       = 1954\u20132003\n| spouse             = {{plainlist|\n*{{marriage|[[Vivian Cash|Vivian Liberto]]|August 7, 1954|1966|end=divorced}}\n*{{marriage|[[June Carter Cash|June Carter]]|March 1, 1968|May 15, 2003|end=died}}\n}}\n| children           = 5, including [[Rosanne Cash|Rosanne]], [[Cindy Cash|Cindy]] and [[John Carter Cash|John]]\n| relatives          = [[Tommy Cash]] (brother)<br>\n[[Thomas Gabriel (country singer)|Thomas Gabriel]] (grandson)\n| website            = {{URL|johnnycash.com}}\n| module             = {{Infobox military person |embed=yes\n| allegiance    = [[United States]]\n| branch        = [[United States Air Force]]\n| battles         = [[Korean War]]\n| rank          = [[Staff sergeant]]\n| serviceyears  = 1950\u20131954\n}}\n| module2            = {{Infobox musical artist | embed=yes\n| background          = solo_singer\n| genre               = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]<ref name=\"auto2\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/johnny-cash-mn0000816890|title=Johnny Cash &#124; Biography, Albums, Streaming Links|website=AllMusic}}</ref>|[[rockabilly]]<ref name=\"auto2\"/>|{{nowrap|[[rock and roll]]<ref name=\"auto1\">{{Cite web|url=https://www.loudersound.com/features/a-tribute-to-johnny-cash-the-ultimate-rebel-and-rock-star|title=A tribute to Johnny Cash, the ultimate rebel and rock star|first=Howard|last=Johnson|website=Classic Rock Magazine|date=September 12, 2016}}</ref>}}|[[American folk music|folk]]<ref name=\"auto1\"/>|[[blues]]<ref name=\"auto1\"/>}}<!-- Do not alter genres without discussion. -->\n| instrument          = {{hlist|Vocals|guitar}}\n| discography         = {{hlist|[[Johnny Cash albums discography|Albums]]|[[Johnny Cash singles discography|singles]]|[[List of songs recorded by Johnny Cash|songs]]}}\n| label               = {{hlist|[[Sun Records|Sun]]|[[Columbia Records|Columbia]]|[[Mercury Records|Mercury]]|[[American Recordings (record label)|American]]|[[House of Cash]]|[[Legacy Recordings|Legacy]]}}\n| past_member_of = [[The Highwaymen (country supergroup)|The Highwaymen]]\n}}\n}}\n'''John R. Cash''' (born '''J. R. Cash'''; February 26, 1932 \u2013 September 12, 2003) was an American singer-songwriter. Most of Cash's music contains themes of sorrow, moral tribulation, and redemption, especially songs from the later stages of his career.<ref name=\"Parales\" /><ref name=\"Mulligan\">{{Citation|last=Mulligan|first=J.|title=Johnny Cash: American VI: Ain't No Grave|date=February 24, 2010|url=http://entertainment.ie/album-review/Johnny-Cash--American-VI-Ain%27t-No-Grave/6891.htm|website=Entertainment.ie|type=album review|access-date=March 22, 2010}}</ref> He was known for his deep, calm, [[bass-baritone]] voice,{{Refn|group=\"lower-alpha\"|Although Cash's [[voice type]] endured over the years, his [[timbre]] changed noticeably. Pareles writes: \"Through a recording career that stretches back to 1955, Cash's bass-baritone voice has gone from gravelly to grave.\"<ref name=\"Parales\">{{cite news |last1=Pareles |first1=Jon |title=Pop Review; Johnny Cash, Austerely Direct From Deep Within |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/09/16/arts/pop-review-johnny-cash-austerely-direct-from-deep-within.html |newspaper=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=February 26, 2019 |date=September 16, 1994}}</ref>}}{{Sfn|Urbanski|2003|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=x_dK-0HfHUYC xiv]}} the distinctive sound of his backing band, [[the Tennessee Three]], that was characterized by its train-like chugging guitar rhythms, a rebelliousness<ref name=\"Dickie\">{{Cite book|last=Dickie|first=M.|url=https://archive.org/details/ringoffire00mich|title=Ring of fire: The Johnny Cash reader|publisher=Da Capo|year=2002|isbn=9780306811227|editor-last=Streissguth|editor-first=M.|place=Cambridge, MA|pages=[https://archive.org/details/ringoffire00mich/page/201 201]\u2013205|contribution=Hard talk from the God-fearin', pro-metal man in Black|orig-year=1987|url-access=registration}}</ref><ref name=\"Streissguth_profile\">{{Cite book|last=Streissguth|first=M.|url=https://archive.org/details/johnnycashbiogra00stre_0|title=Johnny Cash: a biography|publisher=Da Capo|year=2006|isbn=9780306813689|place=Philadelphia, PA|page=[https://archive.org/details/johnnycashbiogra00stre_0/page/196 196]|url-access=registration}}</ref> coupled with an increasingly somber and humble demeanor,<ref name=\"Parales\" /> and his free prison concerts.<ref name=\"Fox\">{{Citation|last=Fox|first=JA|title=Hard time's never a 'circus'|date=October 17, 2005|url=http://www.baylor.edu/pr/bitn/news.php?action=story&story=37416|newspaper=The Boston Herald|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060920020148/http://www.baylor.edu/pr/bitn/news.php?action=story&story=37416|publisher=[[Baylor University]]|access-date=March 22, 2010|archive-date=September 20, 2006|url-status=dead}}</ref> Cash wore a trademark all-black stage wardrobe, which earned him the [[Honorific nicknames in popular music|nickname]] \"[[Man in Black (song)|Man in Black]]\".{{Refn|group=\"lower-alpha\"|For Cash, black stage attire was a \"symbol of rebellion\u2014against a stagnant status quo, against&nbsp;... hypocritical houses of God, against people whose minds are closed to others' ideas\".<ref name=\"Page 64\"/>}}\n\nBorn to poor cotton farmers in [[Kingsland, Arkansas]], Cash grew up on gospel music and played on a local radio station in high school. He served four years in the [[United States Air Force|Air Force]], much of it in West Germany. After his return to the United States, he rose to fame during the mid-1950s in the burgeoning [[rockabilly]] scene in [[Memphis, Tennessee]]. He traditionally began his concerts by introducing himself with \"Hello, I'm Johnny Cash\".{{Refn|group=\"lower-alpha\" | Schultz refers to this phrase as Cash's \"trademark greeting\", and places his utterance of this line, on Cash's ''[[At Folsom Prison]]'' album, \"among the most electrifying [seconds] in the history of concert recording.\"<ref name=\"Schultz\">{{Citation|last=Schultz|first=B.|date=July 1, 2000|url=http://mixonline.com/mag/audio_classic_tracks_johnny|title=Classic Tracks: Johnny Cash's 'Folsom Prison Blues' |newspaper=[[Mix (magazine)|Mix]]|access-date=March 22, 2010|url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100102091058/http://mixonline.com/mag/audio_classic_tracks_johnny/|archive-date=January 2, 2010}}</ref>}} He began to follow that by \"[[Folsom Prison Blues]]\", one of his [[signature song]]s. His other signature songs include \"[[I Walk the Line]]\", \"[[Ring of Fire (song)|Ring of Fire]]\", \"[[Get Rhythm]]\", and \"[[Man in Black (song)|Man in Black]]\".
