Times]]|access-date=January 20, 2010}}</ref><ref name=\"PRX\">{{Citation|publisher=[[Public Radio Exchange]]|year=2010|url=http://www.prx.org/pieces/18385-johnny-cash-amazing-grace|title=Johnny Cash: Amazing Grace|access-date=January 20, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last1=Cash |first1=Johnny |title=Man in White |date=2008 |publisher=[[Thomas Nelson (publisher)|Thomas Nelson]] |isbn=978-1595548368 |page=xiii |edition=Paperback |quote=\"I'm a Christian\" [I said.] \"Don't put me in another box.\"}}</ref><ref name=\"BBCNews\">{{Citation|publisher=BBC News |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/481392.stm|title=Obituary: Johnny Cash |access-date=January 20, 2010|date=September 12, 2003 |postscript=.}}</ref>\n\nIn the mid-1970s, Cash and his wife, June, completed a course of study in the Bible through Christian International Bible College, culminating in a pilgrimage to Israel in November 1978.<ref name=\"John Carter Cash\" />{{rp|66}} Around that time, he was ordained as a minister, and officiated at his daughter's wedding.<ref>{{Cite web|last=Ceretti|first=Evan|date=June 14, 2021|title=6 Interesting Facts About Johnny Cash|url=https://www.roadiemusic.com/blog/6-interesting-facts-about-johnny-cash/|access-date=January 17, 2022|website=Roadie Music Blog }}</ref>  He often performed at [[Billy Graham]] Crusades. <ref> Juli Thanki, [https://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/music/2018/02/21/johnny-cash-billy-graham-friend-and-confidant/358911002/ For Johnny Cash, Billy Graham was friend and confidant], tennessean.com, USA, February 21, 2018</ref> At a Tallahassee Crusade in 1986, June and Johnny sang his song \"One of These Days I'm Gonna Sit Down and Talk to Paul\".<ref>{{cite web |title=Johnny & June Cash on Billy Graham 1986 |website=YouTube |author=((13jalopy)) |date=June 17, 2011 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MlXGSi4rxf8 |url-status=live |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230901121829/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=MlXGSi4rxf8 |archive-date= September 1, 2023 }}</ref>  At a performance in Arkansas in 1989, Johnny Cash spoke to attendees of his commitment to the salvation of drug dealers and alcoholics. He then sang, \"Family Bible\".<ref>{{Cite web |author=pd bredon |title=1989 Johnny Cash (Billy Graham Crusade, Little Rock, Arkansas) (Family Bible) |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8p5Sd_qcBSQ |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170330213636/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8p5Sd_qcBSQ |archive-date=March 30, 2017 |website=YouTube}}</ref>\n\nHe recorded several gospel albums and made a spoken-word recording of the entire [[New King James Version]] of the [[New Testament]].<ref name=\"Rivkin\">{{Citation|editor-last=Rivkin|editor-first=D.|year=2007|title=Johnny Cash reading the complete New Testament|edition=deluxe|type=audio recording|place=Nashville, TN|publisher=Thomas Nelson}}</ref><ref name=\"Morris\">{{Citation|last=Morris|first=E.|date=December 23, 2008|url=http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1601820/johnny-cashs-reading-of-the-new-testament-now-on-dvd.jhtml|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081226013144/http://www.cmt.com/news/country-music/1601820/johnny-cashs-reading-of-the-new-testament-now-on-dvd.jhtml|url-status=dead|archive-date=December 26, 2008|title=Johnny Cash's reading of the New Testament now on DVD|publisher=[[Country Music Television]]|access-date=January 20, 2010}}</ref>  Cash declared he was \"the biggest sinner of them all\", and viewed himself overall as a complicated and contradictory man.{{Sfn|Urbanski|2003|pp=xx\u2013xxi}}{{Refn|name=\"Urbanski_black\"|group=\"lower-alpha\"|Urbanski{{Sfn|Urbanski|2003|p=39}} notes that Cash's habit of performing in black attire began in a church.  In the following paragraph, he{{Sfn|Urbanski|2003|pp=39\u201340}} quotes Cash<ref name=\"Page 64\">{{cite book |last1=Cash |first1=Johnny |last2=Carr |first2=Patrick |title=Cash: The Autobiography |date=2003 |publisher=Harper Collins |page= 64 |url=https://books.google.com/books | isbn=0060727535 |access-date=February 26, 2019}}</ref> as indicating that this habit was partially reflective of Cash's rebellion \"against our hypocritical houses of God.}}  Accordingly,{{Refn|group=\"lower-alpha\"|name=\"Urbanski2\"|According to Urbanski, Cash's self-perception was accurate: \"He never intended to be categorized or pigeonholed\", and indeed he amassed a \"cluster of enigmas\" which \"was so impenetrably deep that even those closest to him never got to see every part of him\".<ref>{{Cite web|last=Urbanski|first=D.|year=2010|url=http://www.relevantmagazine.com/culture/music/features/20625-johnny-cashs-complicated-christianity|title=Johnny Cash's complicated faith: Unwrapping the enigma of the Man in Black|newspaper=[[Relevant Magazine]]|access-date=March 22, 2010|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100227004509/http://www.relevantmagazine.com/culture/music/features/20625-johnny-cashs-complicated-christianity|archive-date=February 27, 2010|df=mdy-all}}</ref>}}  Cash is said to have \"contained multitudes\", and has been deemed \"the philosopher-prince of American country music.\"<ref name=\"Huss\">{{Citation|editor1-last=Huss|editor1-first=J.|editor2-last=Werther|editor2-first=D.|year=2008|title=Johnny Cash and philosophy: The burning ring of truth|place=Chicago, IL|publisher=Open Court}}</ref><ref name=\"Open Court\">{{Citation|publisher=Open Court |year=2007 |url=http://www.opencourtbooks.com/books_n/johnny.htm |title=Johnny Cash and philosophy |access-date=March 22, 2010 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100328113241/http://www.opencourtbooks.com/books_n/johnny.htm |archive-date=March 28, 2010 }}</ref>\n\nCash is credited with having converted actor and singer [[John Schneider (screen actor)|John Schneider]] to Christianity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/tc/2004/001/12.67.html |title=Taking the Lead \u2013 Today's Christian |access-date=April 28, 2015 |url-status=bot: unknown |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080410191111/http://www.christianitytoday.com/tc/2004/001/12.67.html |archive-date=April 10, 2008 }}</ref>\n\nTowards the end of his life, he and his wife attended the First [[Baptist Church]] in [[Hendersonville, Tennessee]]. <ref> Timothy Cockes, [https://www.baptistpress.com/resource-library/news/johnny-cash-documentary-tells-faith-journey-of-man-in-black/ Johnny Cash documentary tells faith journey of Man in Black], baptistpress.com, USA, December 1, 2022 </ref>\n\n== Legacy ==\n[[File:Phoenix-Musical Instrument Museum-Johnny Cash exhibit.jpg|250px|thumb|The clothes and guitar of Johnny Cash on exhibit in the Artist Gallery of the Musical Instrument Museum of Phoenix]]\nCash nurtured and defended artists (such as Bob Dylan<ref name=\"pc10\" />) on the fringes of what was acceptable in country music even while serving as the country music establishment's most visible symbol. At an all-star concert which aired in 1999 on [[TNT (American TV network)|TNT]], a diverse group of artists paid him tribute, including Dylan, [[Chris Isaak]], [[Wyclef Jean]], [[Norah Jones]], Kris Kristofferson, Willie Nelson, [[Dom DeLuise]], and U2. Cash himself appeared at the end and performed for the first time in more than a year. Two tribute albums were released shortly before his death; ''[[Kindred Spirits: A Tribute to the Songs of Johnny Cash|Kindred Spirits]]'' contains works from established artists, while ''[[Dressed in Black: A Tribute to Johnny Cash|Dressed in Black]]'' contains works from many lesser-known musicians.\n\nIn total, he wrote over 1,000 songs and released dozens of albums. A [[box set]] titled ''[[Unearthed (Johnny Cash album)|Unearthed]]'' was issued posthumously. It included four CDs of unreleased material recorded with Rubin, as well as a ''Best of Cash on American'' retrospective CD. The set also includes a 104-page book that discusses each track and features one of Cash's final interviews.<ref>{{cite magazine|title=Cash's ''Unearthed'' box set|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/68530/cashs-unearthed-box-set-unveiled|magazine=Billboard|date=October 22, 2003|access-date=December 11, 2015}}</ref>\n\nIn 1999, Cash received the [[Grammy Lifetime Achievement Award]]. In 2004, ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' ranked Cash number 31 on their \"100 Greatest Artists of All Time\" list<ref>{{cite magazine|last=Kristofferson|first=Kris|title=Johnny Cash, No. 31|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5940054/31_johnny_cash|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060521064830/http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5940054/31_johnny_cash/|url-status=dead|archive-date=May 21, 2006|magazine=Rolling Stone|access-date=December 31, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine|title=The Immortals: The First Fifty|magazine=Rolling Stone|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5939214/the_immortals_the_first_fifty|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060316103016/http://www.rollingstone.com/news/story/5939214/the_immortals_the_first_fifty/|url-status=dead|archive-date=March 16, 2006|access-date=December 31, 2007}}</ref> and No. 21 on their \"100 Greatest Singers\" list in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-singers-of-all-time-19691231/johnny-cash-20101202|title=100 Greatest Singers of All Time|website=Rollingstone.com|date=December 3, 2010|access-date=September 2, 2017|archive-date=July 1, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180701194037/https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-singers-of-all-time-19691231/johnny-cash-20101202|url-status=dead}}</ref> In 2012, ''Rolling Stone'' ranked Cash's 1968 live album ''At Folsom Prison'' and 1994 studio album ''American Recordings'' at No. 88<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/500-greatest-albums-of-all-time-20120531/johnny-cash-at-folsom-prison-20120524|title=500 Greatest Albums of All Time|website=Rollingstone.com|date=May 31, 2012|access-date=September 2, 2017|archive-date=August 18, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170818103831/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/500-greatest-albums-of-all-time-20120531/johnny-cash-at-folsom-prison-20120524|url-status=dead}}</ref> and No. 366<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/500-greatest-albums-of-all-time-20120531/johnny-cash-american-recordings-20120524|title=500 Greatest Albums of All Time|website=Rollingstone.com|date=May 31, 2012|access-date=September 2, 2017|archive-date=September 27, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170927160321/http://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/500-greatest-albums-of-all-time-20120531/johnny-cash-american-recordings-20120524|url-status=dead}}</ref> in its list of the 500 greatest albums of all time.\n\nIn recognition of his lifelong support of [[SOS Children's Villages]], his family invited friends and fans to donate to the Johnny Cash Memorial Fund in his memory. He had a personal link with the SOS village in [[Die\u00dfen am Ammersee|Die\u00dfen]], at the [[Ammersee]] Lake in [[Bavaria]], near where he was stationed as a [[G.I. (military)|GI]], and with the SOS village in Barrett Town, by [[Montego Bay]], near his holiday home in [[Jamaica]].<ref>{{Citation|title=Celebrities as partners|url=http://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/Get-involved/Celebrities-as-partners/Pages/Johnny-Cash.aspx|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518093650/http://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/Get-involved/Celebrities-as-partners/Pages/Johnny-Cash.aspx|url-status=dead|contribution=Johnny Cash|publisher=SOS Children's Villages|archive-date=May 18, 2008}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|title=Supporters|url=https://www.sos-usa.org/about-sos/sos-supporters/johnny-cash|contribution=Johnny Cash|place=USA|publisher=SOS Children's Villages|access-date=June 18, 2018|archive-date=June 18, 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180618175336/https://www.sos-usa.org/about-sos/sos-supporters/johnny-cash|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nIn January 2006, Cash's lakeside home on Caudill Drive in Hendersonville was sold to [[Bee Gees]] vocalist [[Barry Gibb]] and wife Linda for $2.3&nbsp;million. On April 10, 2007, during major renovation works carried out for Gibb, a fire broke out at the house, spreading quickly due to a flammable wood preservative that had been used. The building was completely destroyed.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/6543503.stm|title=Fire destroys Johnny Cash house|date=April 11, 2007|access-date=September 29, 2010|website=BBC}}</ref>\n\nOne of Cash's final collaborations with producer Rick Rubin, ''American V: A Hundred Highways'', was released posthumously on July 4, 2006. The album debuted at number one on the ''Billboard'' Top 200 album chart for the week ending July 22, 2006. On February 23, 2010, three days before what would have been Cash's 78th birthday, the Cash Family, Rick Rubin, and Lost Highway Records released his second posthumous record, titled ''[[American VI: Ain't No Grave]]''.\n\nThe main street in Hendersonville, Tennessee, Highway 31E, is known as \"Johnny Cash Parkway\".<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-2000-12-24-0012240131-story.html|title=NASHVILLE COUNTRY|last=Bordsen, Ridder|date=December 24, 2000|work=The Chicago Tribune|access-date=February 24, 2019}}</ref> The Johnny Cash Museum, located in one of Cash's properties in Hendersonville until 2006, dubbed the [[House of Cash]], was sold based on Cash's will. Prior to this, having been closed for a number of years, the museum had been featured in Cash's music video for \"Hurt\". The house subsequently burned down during the renovation by the new owner. A new museum, founded by Shannon and Bill Miller, opened April 26, 2013, in downtown Nashville.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Rutz|first1=Heather|title=Lima native creative director at new Johnny Cash museum|url=http://search.ebscohost.com/login.aspx?direct=true&db=nfh&AN=2W6897592769&site=ehost-live|access-date=December 11, 2015|publisher=The Lima News|date=June 7, 2013}}</ref>\n\nOn November 2\u20134, 2007, the Johnny Cash Flower Pickin' Festival was held in Starkville, Mississippi, where Cash had been arrested more than 40 years earlier and held overnight at the city jail on May 11, 1965. The incident inspired Cash to write the song \"Starkville City Jail\". The festival, where he was offered a symbolic posthumous pardon, honored Cash's life and music, and was expected to become an annual event.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mississippi town to honor the 'Man in Black'|date=September 6, 2007 |publisher=NBC News|url=https://www.nbcnews.com/id/wbna20611738|access-date=December 31, 2007}}</ref>\n\nJC Unit One, Johnny Cash's private tour bus from 1980 until 2003, was put on exhibit at the [[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]] and Museum in [[Cleveland, Ohio]], in 2007. The museum offers public tours of the bus on a seasonal basis (it is stored during the winter and not exhibited during those times).<ref>{{cite news|last1=Soeder|first1=John|title=Johnny Cash's tour bus returns to Rock and Roll Hall of Fame and Museum|url=http://www.cleveland.com/popmusic/index.ssf/2010/05/johnny_cashs_tour_bus_returns.html|access-date=December 11, 2015|newspaper=The Plain Dealer|date=May 19, 2010}}</ref>\n\nA [[Special edition|limited-edition]] [[Forever stamp]] honoring Cash went on sale June 5, 2013. The stamp features a promotional picture of Cash taken around the 1963 release of ''[[Ring of Fire: The Best of Johnny Cash]]''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Johnny Cash Stamp Release Celebrated By Family|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/2013/06/03/johnny-cash-stamp_n_3377704.html|work=Huffington Post|access-date=June 3, 2013|date=June 3, 2013}}</ref>\n\nOn October 14, 2014, the City of Folsom unveiled phase 1 of the Johnny Cash Trail to the public with a dedication and ribbon-cutting ceremony attended by Rosanne Cash. Along the trail, eight larger-than-life public art pieces will tell the story of Johnny Cash, his connection to Folsom Prison, and his epic musical career. The Johnny Cash Trail features art selected by a committee that included [[Cindy Cash]], a {{convert|2|acre|adj=on}} Legacy Park, and over {{convert|3|mile}} of multi-use class-I bike trail. The artists responsible for the sculptures are Sacramento-based Romo Studios, LLC and the Fine Art Studio of Rotblatt Amrany, from Illinois.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.folsom.ca.us/city_hall/depts/parks/parks_n_trails/trails/johnny_cask.asp|title=Folsom, CA \u2013 Johnny Cash Trail & Art Experience|website=Folsom.ca.us|access-date=January 13, 2017|archive-date=January 16, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170116161524/https://www.folsom.ca.us/city_hall/depts/parks/parks_n_trails/trails/johnny_cask.asp|url-status=dead}}</ref>\n\nIn 2015, a new species of black [[tarantula]] was identified near Folsom Prison and named ''[[Aphonopelma johnnycashi]]'' in his honor.\n\nIn 2016, the [[Nashville Sounds]] [[Minor League Baseball]] team added the \"Country Legends Race\" to its between-innings entertainment. At the middle of the fifth inning, people in oversized foam caricature costumes depicting Cash, as well as [[George Jones]], [[Reba McEntire]], and [[Dolly Parton]], race around the warning track at [[First Horizon Park]] from center field to the home plate side of the first base dugout.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.tennessean.com/picture-gallery/sports/2016/04/07/opening-night-at-first-tennessee-park/82771440/|title=Opening Night at First Tennessee Park|date=April 7, 2016|website=[[The Tennessean]]|access-date=April 8, 2016}}</ref>\n\nOn February 8, 2018, the album ''[[Forever Words]]'' was announced, putting music to poems that Cash had written and which were published in book form in 2016.<ref name=\"forever\">{{cite web |url=https://www.avclub.com/elvis-costello-chris-cornell-and-more-helped-turn-som-1822849331 |title=Elvis Costello, Chris Cornell, and More Helped Turn Some Johnny Cash Poems into Songs |last=Barsanti |first=Sam |date=February 8, 2018 |publisher=[[Univision]] |work=[[The A.V. Club]]}}</ref>\n\nJohnny Cash's boyhood home in Dyess was listed in the [[National Register of Historic Places]] on May 2, 2018, as \"[[Farm No. 266\u2014Johnny Cash Boyhood Home|Farm No. 266, Johnny Cash Boyhood Home]].\"<ref name= Bowden/>\n\nThe Arkansas Country Music Awards honored Johnny Cash's legacy with the Lifetime Achievement award on June 3, 2018. The ceremony was held that same date, which was a Monday night at the [[University of Arkansas at Little Rock]] in [[Little Rock, Arkansas]]. The nominations took place in early 2018.<ref>{{cite web |title=Johnny Cash |url=https://arkansascma.com/recipients |website=Arkansas Country Music Awards Nominees |access-date=January 8, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190109062231/https://arkansascma.com/recipients |archive-date=January 9, 2019 |url-status=dead }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Winners of inaugural Arkansas Country Music Awards announced |url=https://www.arkansasonline.com/news/2018/jun/05/winners-inaugural-arkansas-country-music-awards-an/ |website=Arkansas Online |access-date=January 9, 2019 |date=June 5, 2018}}</ref>\n\nIn 2019, [[Sheryl Crow]] released a duet with Cash on her song \"Redemption Day\" for her album ''[[Threads (Sheryl Crow album)|Threads]]''. Crow, who had originally written and recorded the song in 1996, recorded new vocals and added them to those of Cash, who recorded the song for his ''[[American VI: Ain't No Grave]]'' album.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.udiscovermusic.com/news/sheryl-crow-shares-powerful-duet-johnny-cash-redemption-day/|title=Sheryl Crow Shares Powerful \"Duet\" With Johnny Cash, 'Redemption Day'|first=Paul|last=Sexton|date=April 21, 2019}}</ref>\n\nIn April 2019, it was announced that the state of Arkansas would place a statue of Cash in the [[National Statuary Hall]] in an effort to represent the modern history of Arkansas. The Governor of Arkansas, [[Asa Hutchinson]], stated that Cash's contributions to music made him an appropriate figure to tell the story of the state.<ref>{{cite news|title=Johnny Cash to replace Confederate statue on Capitol Hill|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/johnny-cash-to-replace-confederate-statue-on-capitol-hill/2019/04/17/27058054-6153-11e9-9412-daf3d2e67c6d_story.html?noredirect=on|author=Colby Itkowitz|newspaper=The Washington Post|date=April 17, 2019}}</ref>\n\nIn April 2024, unfinished and unreleased demos recorded by Cash were announced to be released in a new compilation album, ''[[Songwriter (Johnny Cash album)|Songwriter]]''. The album \u2013 co-produced by Cash's son, [[John Carter Cash]] \u2013 contains eleven songs, recorded in 1993 with guest artists including [[Vince Gill]] and [[the Black Keys]]. ''Songwriter''{{'}}s release date was announced as June 28, 2024.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Beaumont-Thomas |first=Ben |date=2024-04-23 |title=Lost Johnny Cash songs from 1993 to be released as a new album |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2024/apr/23/lost-johnny-cash-songs-songwriter-demos-album |access-date=2024-04-23 |work=The Guardian |language=en-GB |issn=0261-3077}}</ref>\n\n=== Portrayals ===\nCountry singer [[Mark Collie]] portrayed Cash in [[John Lloyd Miller]]'s [[John Lloyd Miller#Awards|award-winning]] 1999 short film ''I Still Miss Someone''.\n\nIn November 2005, ''[[Walk the Line]]'', a biographical film about Cash's life, was released in the United States to considerable commercial success and critical acclaim. The film featured [[Joaquin Phoenix]] as Johnny (for which he was nominated for the [[Academy Award for Best Actor]]) and [[Reese Witherspoon]] as June (for which she won the [[Academy Award for Best Actress]]). Phoenix and Witherspoon also won the [[Golden Globe]] for Best Actor in a Musical or Comedy and Best Actress in a Musical or Comedy, respectively. They both performed their own vocals in the film (with their version of \"Jackson\" being released as a single), and Phoenix learned to play guitar for the role. Phoenix received a Grammy Award for his contributions to the soundtrack. John Carter Cash, the son of Johnny and June, served as an executive producer.\n\nOn March 12, 2006, ''[[Ring of Fire (musical)|Ring of Fire]]'', a [[jukebox musical]] of the Cash oeuvre, debuted on Broadway at the [[Ethel Barrymore Theater]], but closed due to harsh reviews and disappointing sales on April 30. ''[[Million Dollar Quartet (musical)|Million Dollar Quartet]]'', a musical portraying the early Sun recording sessions involving Cash, Elvis Presley, Jerry Lee Lewis, and Carl Perkins, debuted on Broadway on April 11, 2010. Actor [[Lance Guest]] portrayed Cash. The musical was nominated for three awards at the [[2010 Tony Awards]] and won one.\n\n[[Robert Hilburn]], veteran ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' pop music critic, the journalist who accompanied Cash in his 1968 Folsom prison tour, and interviewed Cash many times throughout his life including months before his death, published a 688-page biography with 16 pages of photographs in 2013.<ref name=\"Johnny Cash biography\">{{cite book|last=Hilburn|first=Robert|title=Johnny Cash: The Life (Deckle Edge)|year=2013|publisher=Little Brown and Company|location=New York City|isbn=978-0-316-19475-4}}</ref> The meticulously reported biography is said to have filled in the 80% of Cash's life that was unknown, including details about Cash's battles with addiction and infidelity.<ref name=\"Johnny Cash': Meticulous Attention to Facts Sets Robert Hilburn's Biography Apart\">{{cite news|last=Kinchen|first=David|title=BOOK REVIEW: 'Johnny Cash': Meticulous Attention to Facts Sets Robert Hilburn's Biography Apart|url=http://www.huntingtonnews.net/76236|access-date=December 12, 2013|newspaper=Huntington News|date=November 3, 2013|archive-date=December 17, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141217212800/http://www.huntingtonnews.net/76236|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref name=\"LAT Hilburn\">{{cite news|url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment/music/posts/la-et-ms-johnny-cash-calif-story.html|title=Johnny Cash's dark California days|first= Robert |last=Hilburn|date=October 12, 2013|access-date=February 20, 2018|newspaper=[[LA Times]]}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Hilburn|first=Robert|url=https://www.npr.org/2013/10/29/240778989/biography-doesnt-hold-back-on-the-man-in-blacks-darkest-years|title=Interview: Robert Hilburn, Author Of 'Johnny Cash: The Life'|publisher=NPR|date=October 29, 2013|access-date=April 25, 2014}}</ref>\n\n== Awards and honors ==\n{{for|detailed lists of music awards|List of awards received by Johnny Cash}}\n\n{{Quote box|width=28%|align=right|quote=If there were a hall of fame for creating larger-than-life personae, Cash would no doubt have been elected to it as well. His 1971 song \"Man in Black\" codified an image that the singer had assumed naturally for more than fifteen years at that point. Part rural preacher, part outlaw Robin Hood, he was a blue-collar prophet who, dressed in stark contrast to the glinting rhinestones and shimmering psychedelia of the time, spoke truth to power.|source=\u2014Johnny Cash: Remembering the Incomparable Legend of Country, Rock and Roll, ''[[Rolling Stone]]''.<ref name=\"RS Cash\"/>}}\nCash received multiple [[Country Music Association Awards]], Grammys, and other awards, in categories ranging from vocal and spoken performances to album notes and videos. In a career that spanned almost five decades, Cash was the personification of country music to many people around the world. Cash was a musician who was not defined by a single genre. He recorded songs that could be considered [[rock and roll]], [[blues]], [[rockabilly]], [[folk music|folk]], and [[gospel music|gospel]], and exerted an influence on each of those genres.\n\nHis diversity was evidenced by his presence in five major music halls of fame: the [[Nashville Songwriters Hall of Fame]] (1977), the [[Country Music Hall of Fame]] (1980), the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame (1992), GMA's [[Gospel Music Hall of Fame]] (2010). and the [[Memphis Music Hall of Fame]] (2013).<ref>{{Citation|url=http://countrymusichalloffame.org/Inductees/InducteeDetail/johnny-cash|publisher=Country Music Hall of Fame|title=Inductees|contribution=Johnny Cash|access-date=May 2, 2017|archive-date=May 4, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170504125420/http://countrymusichalloffame.org/Inductees/InducteeDetail/johnny-cash|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|url=http://rockhall.com/inductees/johnny-cash|publisher=Rock and Roll Hall of Fame|title=Inductees|contribution=Johnny Cash}}</ref> Marking his death in 2003, ''Rolling Stone'' stated other than [[Elvis Presley]] Cash was the only artist inducted as a performer into both the Country Music Hall of Fame and the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame.<ref name=\"RS Cash\">{{cite news |title=Johnny Cash: Remembering the Incomparable Legend of Country, Rock and Roll |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/johnny-cash-remembering-the-incomparable-legend-of-country-rock-and-roll-244037/ |access-date=April 1, 2020 |magazine=Rolling Stone}}</ref>\n\nHis contributions to the genre have been recognized by the [[Rockabilly Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web|title=RHOF Inductees with Certificates|publisher=Rockabilly Hall of Fame|url=http://www.rockabillyhall.com/Certificates.html|access-date=December 31, 2007|archive-date=May 18, 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190518131612/http://www.rockabillyhall.com/Certificates.html|url-status=dead}}</ref> Cash received the [[Kennedy Center Honors]] in 1996 and stated that his induction into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 1980 was his greatest professional achievement. In 2001, he was awarded the [[National Medal of Arts]].<ref>{{Citation|url=http://arts.gov/honors/medals/johnny-cash|contribution=Lifetime Honors|title=National Medal of Arts|date=April 24, 2013}}</ref> \"Hurt\" was nominated for six VMAs at the 2003 MTV Video Music Awards. The only VMA the video won was that for Best Cinematography. With the video, Johnny Cash became the oldest artist ever nominated for an MTV Video Music Award.<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.songstuff.com/article/johnny_cash_memories_shared/| title = Johnny Cash \u2013 Memories Shared | website = Songstuff.com| access-date = June 27, 2013}}</ref> [[Justin Timberlake]], who won Best Video that year for \"[[Cry Me a River (Justin Timberlake song)|Cry Me a River]]\", said in his acceptance speech: \"This is a travesty! I demand a recount. My grandfather raised me on Johnny Cash, and I think he deserves this more than any of us in here tonight.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.monkeyouttanowhere.com/quotes/archives/2003/08/29_09_23.html |title=Quotables \"August 29, 2003 Justin Timberlake on Johnny Cash\" |access-date=April 5, 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140407063853/http://www.monkeyouttanowhere.com/quotes/archives/2003/08/29_09_23.html |archive-date=April 7, 2014 }}</ref>\n\n== Discography ==\n{{main|Johnny This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Mel_McDaniel","to":"Mel McDaniel"}],"pages":{"2541302":{"pageid":2541302,"ns":0,"title":"Mel McDaniel","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{Short description|American country music singer-songwriter (1942\u20132011)}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=September 2020}}\n{{More citations needed|date=July 2016}}\n{{Infobox musical artist|<!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject Musicians -->\n| name             = Mel McDaniel\n| image            = Mel McDaniel 2006.jpg\n| caption          = McDaniel in 2006\n| image_size       = <!-- Only for images smaller than 220 pixels -->\n| background       = solo_singer\n| birth_name       = Melvin Huston McDaniel\n| alias            = \n| birth_date       = {{Birth date|1942|9|6}}\n| birth_place      = [[Checotah, Oklahoma]], U.S.\n| death_date       = {{Death date and age|2011|3|31|1942|9|6}}\n| death_place      = [[Nashville, Tennessee]], U.S.\n| origin           = [[Okmulgee, Oklahoma]], U.S.\n| instruments      = Vocals, guitar\n| genre            = {{hlist|[[Country music|Country]]|[[Rockabilly]]|[[country rock]]|[[rock and roll]]}}\n| occupation       = Singer-songwriter\n| years_active     = 1975\u20132011\n| label            = [[Capitol Nashville|Capitol]]\n| associated_acts  = [[Chuck Berry]]\n}}\n\n'''Melvin Huston McDaniel''' (September 6, 1942 \u2013 March 31, 2011)<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://themusicsover.com/2011/03/31/mel-mcdaniel/|title=\u00bb Died On This Date (March 31, 2011) Mel McDaniel / Country Music Star |website=Themusicsover.com|access-date=August 8, 2021}}</ref> was an American [[country music]] artist. Many of his top hits were released in the 1980s, including \"[[Louisiana Saturday Night]]\", \"[[Big Ole Brew]]\", \"[[Stand Up (Mel McDaniel song)|Stand Up]]\", \"[[Baby's Got Her Blue Jeans On]]\" (which reached number one on the country chart), \"[[I Call It Love (Mel McDaniel song)|I Call It Love]]\", \"[[Stand on It (Bruce Springsteen song)|Stand on It]]\", and a remake of [[Chuck Berry]]'s \"[[Let It Roll (Let It Rock)]]\".\n\nMcDaniel's type of country music has been referred to as \"the quintessential happy song\" in comparison to other country artists who discuss broken hearts and lost loves. When asked why most of his songs were positive in their outlook, McDaniel told the ''[[Anchorage Daily News]]'' that \"there's enough things in the world to keep you bummed out\" and that his fans did not want to \"hear me singing something that's gonna bum 'em out some more.\"<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=tIIgAAAAIBAJ&sjid=R8AEAAAAIBAJ&pg=2818,1429291&dq=mel+mcdaniel+real+good+feel+good+song&hl=en|title=Good Ol' Boy|last=Perala|first=Andrew|date=October 19, 1989|newspaper=[[Anchorage Daily News]]|access-date=June 14, 2011}}</ref>\n\n==Biography==\n===Early life===\nMcDaniel was born in [[Checotah, Oklahoma]],<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\">{{cite book|title=[[Encyclopedia of Popular Music|The Guinness Who's Who of Country Music]]|editor=[[Colin Larkin (writer)|Colin Larkin]]|publisher=[[Guinness Publishing]]|date=1993|edition=First|isbn=0-85112-726-6|page=249}}</ref> a small town in [[McIntosh County, Oklahoma]], and grew up in [[Okmulgee, Oklahoma]]. He was inspired to play music after seeing [[Elvis Presley]] on television. His first interest in music was when he learned the trumpet in the fourth grade, but he soon learned the guitar.<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> At age 14, he taught himself the guitar chords to \"[[Frankie and Johnny (song)|Frankie and Johnny]]\" and performed at a high-school talent contest. He made his professional debut at age 15 performing in a talent contest at Okmulgee High School. While in high school, he played in several local bands, and after graduation, began working as a musician in [[Tulsa]] clubs. While in Tulsa, he recorded several singles for local label [[J.J. Cale]] and wrote and produced his first single, \"Lazy Me\".<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/>\n\n===Career===\nAfter marrying his high school sweetheart, McDaniel began performing in Tulsa. From there, he had an unsuccessful trip to Nashville, followed by quite a bit of success in [[Anchorage, Alaska]], performing at clubs among the oil fields.<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> After two years there, he returned to Nashville and landed a job as a demo singer and songwriter with Combine Music. With the help of music publisher [[Bob Beckham]], McDaniel signed to [[Capitol Records]] in 1976 and released his first single, \"Have a Dream on Me\".<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/>\n\nHis career finally took off with \"[[Louisiana Saturday Night]]\" in 1981, and in early 1985 he scored his only number one hit with \"[[Baby's Got Her Blue Jeans On]]\".<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/> Other Top 10 hits include \"[[Right in the Palm of Your Hand]]\" (later covered by [[Alan Jackson]] in 1999), \"[[Take Me to the Country (song)|Take Me to the Country]]\", \"[[Big Ole Brew]]\", \"[[I Call It Love (Mel McDaniel song)|I Call It Love]]\", and \"[[Real Good Feel Good Song]]\".<ref name=\"LarkinCountry\"/>\n\nMcDaniel became a member of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] on January 11, 1986, and made frequent appearances on the show.\n\nMcDaniel was inducted into the [[Oklahoma Music Hall of Fame]] in 2006, along with induction classmate [[Leon Russell]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://oklahomamusichalloffame.com/Inductees/BYYEAR/tabid/86/ItemID/17/Default.aspx |title=By Year |access-date=April 1, 2011 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110429194034/http://www.oklahomamusichalloffame.com/Inductees/BYYEAR/tabid/86/ItemID/17/Default.aspx |archive-date=April 29, 2011 }}</ref>\n\n===Later years, health, and death===\nOn November 14, 1996, he had a nearly fatal fall into an orchestra pit while he was performing at the Heymann Performing Arts Center in [[Lafayette, Louisiana]]. The accident ended his touring career, and he underwent several surgeries thereafter. McDaniel never fully recovered from his injuries. On June 16, 2009, McDaniel suffered a heart attack, putting him in a medically induced coma in a Nashville area hospital, according to ''[[The Tennessean]]''.{{citation needed|date=November 2019}} McDaniel's wife, Peggy, requested the prayers of the singer's fans, saying his situation was \"not good.\"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.countryweekly.com/mel_mcdaniel/news/3994/ |title=Mel McDaniel Battles for Life - News - Country Weekly Magazine |access-date=July 7, 2009 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090710013018/http://www.countryweekly.com/mel_mcdaniel/news/3994 |archive-date=July 10, 2009 }}</ref> McDaniel recovered from the heart attack, but on February 19, 2011, he was diagnosed with lung cancer, and died at his home on the evening of March 31, as a result of the disease. He was 68 years old.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theboot.com/2011/04/01/mel-mcdaniel-dead/ |title=Mel McDaniel Dead at 68 |website=Theboot.com |access-date=July 19, 2016}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n{{Main|Mel McDaniel discography}}\n* ''[[I'm Countryfied]]'' (1980)\n\n==Awards and nominations==\n=== Grammy Awards ===\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n|[[28th Grammy Awards|1986]]\n|\"[[Baby's Got Her Blue Jeans On]]\"\n|[[Grammy Award for Best Male Country Vocal Performance|Best Male Country Vocal Performance]]\n|{{nom}}\n|}\n\n=== American Music Awards===\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n|[[American Music Awards of 1987|1987]]\n|Mel McDaniel\n|Favorite Country Male Video Artist\n|{{nom}}\n|}\n\n=== Music City News Country Awards===\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n|[[20th Music City News Country Awards|1986]]\n|\"[[Baby's Got Her Blue Jeans On]]\"\n|Single of the Year\n|{{nom}}\n|}\n\n=== Academy of Country Music Awards ===\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n|[[13th Academy of Country Music Awards|1978]]\n|Mel McDaniel\n|[[Academy of Country Music Award for New Male Artist of the Year|Top New Male Vocalist]]\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n|rowspan=2| [[21st Academy of Country Music Awards|1986]]\n|rowspan=2| \"[[Baby's Got Her Blue Jeans On]]\"\n|Single Record of the Year\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n|Song of the Year\n|{{nom}}\n|}\n\n=== Country Music Association Awards ===\n\n{{awards table}}\n|-\n|rowspan=2| [[1985 Country Music Association Awards|1985]]\n|Mel McDaniel\n|[[Country Music Association Award for New Artist of the Year|Horizon Award]]\n|{{nom}}\n|-\n|\"[[Baby's Got Her Blue Jeans On]]\"\n|[[Country Music Association Award for Single of the Year|Single of the Year]]\n|{{nom}}\n|}\n\n==References==\n{{Reflist}}\n\n==Bibliography==\n*Millard, Bob (1998). \"Mel McDaniel\". This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Jimmy_Lee_Fautheree","to":"Jimmy Lee Fautheree"}],"pages":{"15421772":{"pageid":15421772,"ns":0,"title":"Jimmy Lee Fautheree","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{one source|date=June 2015}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Jimmy Lee Fautheree\n| image            =\n| image_size       =\n| landscape        = <!-- yes, if wide image, otherwise leave blank -->\n| alt              =\n| caption          =\n| birth_name       =\n| native_name      =\n| native_name_lang =\n| alias            =\n| birth_date       = {{birth date|1934|4|11}}\n| birth_place      = [[Smackover, Arkansas]], United States\n| origin           =\n| death_date       = {{death date and age|2004|6|29|1934|4|11}}\n| death_place      = [[Dallas, Texas]], United States\n| genre            = [[Rockabilly]], country\n| occupation       = Singer\n| instrument       =\n| years_active     = <!-- YYYY\u2013YYYY (or \u2013present) -->\n| label            = {{unbulleted list| [[Capitol Records]] | [[Decca Records]] | [[Paula Records]]}}\n| associated_acts  =\n| website          = <!-- {{URL|example.com}} -->\n}}\n'''Jimmy Lee Fautheree''' (April 11, 1934 - June 29, 2004) was an American [[rockabilly]] and country singer.\n\nBorn in [[Smackover, Arkansas]], he began playing guitar at age 12, and was heavily influenced by [[Merle Travis]]. In 1946 his family moved to [[Dallas]], where he played on [[KRLD (AM)|KRLD]]'s ''[[Big D Jamboree]]''. By 1951 he was playing on the ''[[Louisiana Hayride]]''; that year he signed to [[Capitol Records]] and released his first single, \"I Keep the Blues All the Time\", as Jimmy Lee. Capitol released seven further singles from Fautheree before dropping him in 1952. Despite never charting, the recordings have been cited as influential on later rockabilly artists, including [[James Burton]].\n\nFautheree subsequently found work as a [[session musician]] for musicians such as [[Faron Young]] and [[Webb Pierce]]. Along with [[\"Country\" Johnny Mathis]], he performed on ''Louisiana Hayride'' as [[Jimmy & Johnny]], and released a charting single under the \"Jimmy Lee & Johnny Mathis\" moniker on [[Chess Records]], 1954's \"If You Don't, Somebody Else Will\". Fautheree left Mathis to work with Wayne Walker, a partnership that lasted only four months but yielded a few recordings. Following this he began recording with his brother Lynn, again under the name Jimmy & Johnny; they signed to [[Decca Records]], but by 1957 the pair had moved back to Dallas.\n\nFautheree went back to solo recording, recording in [[New Orleans]] in 1958 at J&M Studio. He recorded briefly with Mathis again between 1958 and 1959. Some self-released material and a single on [[Paula Records]] brought him into 1960, and throughout the next decade Fautheree worked increasingly in the genre of [[gospel music]].\n\nBy the 1970s Fautheree had left the business, working in [[asbestos]] removal. In 1995, he returned to music with Mathis, recording a new single, \"It Won't Be Much Longer\", together. He played both in the U.S. and abroad in the 2000s, and released a full-length album with [[Deke Dickerson]] entitled ''I Found the Doorknob''. Shortly after the album was complete he died of [[cancer]] in Dallas on June 29, 2004.\n\nHis mother's name was Lodema Hammonds, the daughter of Mack Hammonds of Maud, Texas, who was a descendant of [[Phillip Hamman]], the Savior of the Greenbrier.\n\n==Discography==\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n! width=\"30\" | Year\n! width=\"350\" | Title\n! width=\"150\" | Record label\n|----\n| 1951 || ''Love Is Hard To Understand / I Keep the Blues All The Time'' || Capitol Records\n|----\n| 1951 || ''Go Ahead and Go / Knocking On Your Front Door'' || Capitol Records\n|----\n| 1951 || ''Lips That Kiss So Sweetly / I\u2019ve Got A Broken Heart'' || Capitol Records \n|----\n| 1952 || ''Suspense / Warm Warm Kisses'' || Capitol Records \n|----\n| 1952 || ''I\u2019m Diggin\u2019 A Hole To Bury My Heart / Kisses By Mail'' || Capitol Records\n|----\n| 1952 || ''Blowin\u2019 And Goin\u2019 / Mistakes'' || Capitol Records\n|----\n| 1953 || ''How About A Date / Cryin\u2019 Won\u2019t Change My Mind'' || Capitol Records\n|----\n| 1955 || ''Lips That Kiss So Sweetly / Love Me'' (with Wayne Walker) || Chess Records\n|----\n| 1958 || ''Teenage Wedding / Baby It\u2019s Love'' (as ''Johnny Angel'') || Vin Records\n|----\n| 1966 || ''Git / Can\u2019t Find The Doorknob'' || Paula Records  \n|----\n| 1966 || ''Keep Me In Mind / Belle Of Monterrey'' || Paula Records\n|----\n| 1974 || ''Project X-9 (Instr.) / I\u2019m The Laziest Man In The World'' || Lodema Records\n|----\n| 197? [[rockabilly]] band<ref name=\"express\"/> from [[Sylvan Lake, Alberta]] composed of Ryan Langlois, Joel Rathjen, Teddy Roy Michaylow, Ben Shillabeer and Neil MacDonald.<ref name=\"cbc\">{{cite web|title=The Boom Chucka Boys on CBC Music|url=http://music.cbc.ca/#/artists/The-Boom-Chucka-Boys|website=[[CBC Music]]|accessdate=September 11, 2014}}</ref> The band was formed in July 2010.<ref name=\"cbc\" /><ref name=\"express\">{{cite news|last1=Weber|first1=Mark|title=Boom Chucka Boys unleash 'rockabilly and classic country'|url=http://www.reddeerexpress.com/entertainment/Boom_Chucka_Boys_unleash_rockabilly_and_classic_country_211255751.html|accessdate=September 11, 2014|work=Red Deer Express|date=June 12, 2013}}</ref> They were discovered by [[Gord Bamford]] in January 2011 and signed a record deal with his company, Cache Entertainment.<ref name=\"express\" /><ref name=\"college\">{{cite news|last1=Ledingham|first1=Lani|title=The Boom Chucka Boys will make you shake your boogie woogie|url=http://rdc.ab.ca/about/alumni-foundation/alumni/blog/boom-chucka-boys-will-make-you-shake-your-boogie-woogie|accessdate=September 11, 2014|work=[[Red Deer College]]|date=February 14, 2014}}</ref>\n\nTheir self-titled debut album was released in April 2013 and distributed by [[Sony Music Canada]].<ref name=\"college\" /> It was produced by [[Byron Hill]] and recorded in [[Nashville, Tennessee]].<ref name=\"cbc\" /> The first single, \"Find My Peace of Mind\", was released in March 2013 and peaked at number 43 on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Canada Country]] chart.<ref name=\"Canada Country\" /> In 2014, The Boom Chucka Boys were nominated for the [[Canadian Country Music Association]] Award for Group or Duo of the Year.<ref name=\"advocate\">{{cite news|last1=Michelin|first1=Lana|title=Boom Chucka Boys have shot at country music group of 2014}}</ref> The band signed with [[Royalty Records]] in 2014 and released their second album, ''Ramble'', on February 10, 2015.<ref name=\"advocate\" /> The album features three singles: \"Turn This Car Around\" released in October 2014, \"Rebel Wings\" released in February 2015 and \"Can't Take My Lips Off You\" released in August 2015.\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| description|American singer-songwriter}}\n\n{{BLP sources|date=November 2012}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name             = Unknown Hinson\n| image            = Unknown Hinson 2010 (cropped).jpg\n| image_size       = \n| caption          = Unknown Hinson performing in 2010\n| birth_name       = Stuart Daniel Baker\n| birth_date       = {{birth date and age|1954|11|7}}\n| origin           = [[Albemarle, North Carolina]], U.S.\n| instrument       = \n| occupation       = {{Flatlist|\n* Musician\n* songwriter\n* voice actor\n}}\n| genre            = {{Flatlist|\n* [[Rockabilly]]\n* [[Country music|country]]\n* [[psychobilly]]\n}}\n| years_active     = 1992\u20132023 <ref>{{cite news |last1=Rich |first1=Jonathan |title=The weird, wicked world of Unknown Hinson |url=https://www.blueridgenow.com/news/20061027/the-weird-wicked-world-of-unknown-hinson |work=Hendersonville Times-News |date=October 27, 2006 |language=en}}</ref>\n| label            = Uniphone, [[Capitol Records|Capitol]], Coffin Case\n| past_member_of    = [[The Boxmasters]]\n| website          = \n}}\n\n'''Stuart Daniel Baker''' (born November 7, 1954), known by his stage name '''Unknown Hinson''', is an American singer, musician, songwriter, and voice actor.<ref>{{cite web |title= Squidbillies Characters  |url= http://www.adultswim.com/shows/squidbillies/indexpage.html#characters |publisher = AdultSwim.com |access-date= January 5, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title= It's good to be King: Unknown Hinson is a legend of his own making  |url= http://www.thedailytimes.com/article/20080815/ENT/20211794 |publisher = TheDailyTimes.Com |access-date= August 14, 2008}}</ref> He was the longtime voice of Early Cuyler in the [[Adult animation|adult]] [[animated sitcom]] ''[[Squidbillies]]'' from 2005 to 2019.\n\n==Biography==\nStuart Daniel Baker, a music teacher and studio musician from [[Albemarle, North Carolina]], created his alter-ego for ''The Wild Wild South'', a Charlotte-area public-access program that featured comedy sketches and concert footage. Baker and co-star Don Swan played the characters of Unknown Hinson and Rebel Helms, respectively. After Swan's death in 1995, Baker created ''The Unknown Hinson Show'', a direct spin-off of ''The Wild Wild South''. ''The Unknown Hinson Show'' won [[Creative Loafing|Creative Loafing Charlotte's]] \"Best Of\" poll for Best Public-Access Television Show four years in a row.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mountainx.com/ae/1999/1027unknown.php |title=Into the Unknown &#124; Asheville Arts and Entertainment &#124; Mountain Xpress |publisher=Mountainx.com |access-date=August 13, 2011}}</ref> After the series ended, Baker continued in his role as Unknown Hinson, performing live concerts and releasing several recordings.\n\n==Career==\n\n===Live performing career===\nHinson has performed with many notable [[rockabilly]], [[country music|country]], and [[psychobilly]] acts such as [[The Reverend Horton Heat]], [[Marty Stuart]], [[Hank III]], and [[Ed King]]. Hank III, grandson of [[Hank Williams]], has Hinson's face tattooed on his bicep.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.boiseweekly.com/boise/inside-the-heathen-mind-of-hank-iii/Content?oid=929012 | title=Inside the Heathen Mind of Hank III: An interview with country music's self-exiled prince |publisher=[[Boise Weekly]] | date=August 9, 2006| access-date=November 18, 2015}}</ref>\nIn late 2008, working under the name Danny Baker, Hinson was hired to play bass as well as lead guitar in Billy Bob Thornton's band The Boxmasters. For this  gig, Baker appears without the familiar Unknown Hinson wardrobe and makeup, instead appearing in a vintage '60s suit, white shirt, and black pencil tie. His manager and booking agent was his wife, Margo Baker.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/charlotte/obituary.aspx?pid=163309087#fbLoggedOut |title=Margo Elizabeth Cogan Baker Obituary: View Margo Baker's Obituary by Charlotte Observer |publisher=[[Legacy.com]] |access-date=September 4, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.answers.com/topic/unknown-hinson |title=Unknown Hinson: Information from |publisher=[[Answers.com]] |access-date=September 4, 2013}}</ref>\n\nAccording to a November 10, 2012 post on his Facebook page, Hinson decided to quit touring after 17 years. He cited rising costs and indicated his plans to find something new to do. After the death of his wife, Margo Baker, Unknown Hinson resumed touring again.\n\nOn June 3, 2020, Baker announced on his Facebook page that he would not be playing any more shows due to [[osteoarthritis]].<ref>{{Cite web|last=Hinson|first=Unknown|date=June 3, 2020|title=My dear friends, Unfortunately I don't...|url=https://www.facebook.com/Officialunknownhinsonstuartbaker/photos/a.250536291967520/1159941584360315/?type=3&theater|publisher=Facebook.com}}</ref> On July 17, 2023, he announced on his Facebook page that he was recovering from two strokes and undergoing physical therapy.<ref>[https://www.facebook.com/Officialunknownhinsonstuartbaker/posts/pfbid02rLvnEmaffWWQuQqGZyaHM4gKzyQXMXQsZ8m8uuLYwk1kUaBuphGS1NT5tMATRVuRl Facebook post from July 17, 2023]</ref>\n\n===Recording career===\n[[File:Unknown Hinson.jpg|thumb|upright|Hinson in 2009]]\nUnknown Hinson wrote his own music, and produced all of his own recordings. His music often parodied the dark elements of contemporary country and redneck culture. In early 2009, Hinson's \"Torture Town\" won in The 8th Annual Independent Music Awards and Vox Pop vote for Best Alternative Country.\n\n===Voice acting career===\nHinson, credited as Baker, provided the voice of Early Cuyler, a balding hillbilly squid from [[Georgia (US state)|Georgia]], on [[Cartoon Network]]'s late night [[Adult Swim]] program ''[[Squidbillies]]'' for 15 years.<ref name=\"yasharoff\">{{Cite news|last=Yasharoff|first=Hannah|title='Squidbillies' star Unknown Hinson fired over 'extremely offensive' posts about BLM, Dolly Parton|url=https://www.jacksonville.com/story/entertainment/tv/2020/08/19/squidbillies-star-unknown-hinson-fired-over-blm-dolly-parton-posts/3398793001/|date=August 19, 2020|access-date=August 19, 2020|newspaper=[[The Florida Times-Union]]|language=en-US}}</ref>\n\n==Controversy==\nOn August 13, 2020, Baker received backlash after posting comments about [[Dolly Parton]], calling her a \"bimbo\" and \"slut\" on his Facebook page in response to a recent news article concerning Parton's support of the [[Black Lives Matter]] movement.<ref name=Andrew/> Not long after this post, the Facebook page went offline, but returned on the following day with the posts concerning Parton removed.{{citation needed|date=December 2022}} Baker subsequently posted a response to those who were upset, telling liberals to \"unfriend\" him and telling them to have fun \"forsaking your own race, culture, and heritage.\"<ref name=Andrew>{{cite web|first=Stephen|last=Andrew|title= Unknown Hinson, 'Squidbillies' Star, Goes on Tirade About Dolly Parton's Black Lives Matter Support |url= https://popculture.com/country-music/news/unknown-hinson-squidbillies-star-tirade-dolly-parton-black-lives-matter-support//|date=August 19, 2020|access-date=August 19, 2020|website=Pop Culture}}</ref>\n\nThe producers of ''Squidbillies'' fired Baker from the series over his remarks.<ref name=\"yasharoff\"/> [[Reverend Musical Instruments|Reverend Guitars]] of Ohio abruptly stopped marketing their Stuart Baker signature series guitars on August 14, 2020, and posted, \"we are no longer associated with Unknown Hinson. We have stopped production on his guitars and we have removed him from our website.\"<ref name=\"clodfelter\">{{Cite web|last=Clodfelter|first=Tim|date=August 14, 2020|title=Unknown Hinson in hot water over Dolly Parton comments|url=https://journalnow.com/entertainment/unknown-hinson-in-hot-water-over-dolly-parton-comments/article_31259b90-de62-11ea-8220-576201cd4789.html|access-date=September 1, 2020|website=Winston-Salem Journal|language=en}}</ref>\n\n==Works==\n\n===Discography===\n{| class=\"wikitable\"\n|-\n!Year\n!Album\n!Label\n|-\n| 1999\n| ''[[The Future Is Unknown]]''\n| Uniphone This format is deprecated, and in the future the new format will always be used."}},"query":{"normalized":[{"from":"Mason_Ramsey","to":"Mason Ramsey"}],"pages":{"57105198":{"pageid":57105198,"ns":0,"title":"Mason Ramsey","revisions":[{"contentformat":"text/x-wiki","contentmodel":"wikitext","*":"{{short description|American singer (born 2006)}}\n{{Use American English|date = September 2019}}\n{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2019}}\n{{Infobox musical artist\n| name              = Mason Ramsey\n| image             = {{CSS image crop\n|Image = Mason Ramsey at Grammercy Theater.jpg\n|bSize = 500\n|cWidth = 200\n|cHeight = 270\n|oTop = 200\n|oLeft = 170\n|Location = center\n}}\n| caption           = Ramsey in 2024\n| alias             = Mason Blake\n| birth_date        = {{Birth date and age|2006|11|16|}}<ref name=\"Lindsay-2019\">{{Cite web |last=Lindsay |first=Jessica |date=2019-07-12 |title=Who is Mason Ramsey, the Walmart yodelling kid on the new Old Town Road remix? |url=https://metro.co.uk/2019/07/12/mason-ramsey-walmart-yodelling-kid-new-old-town-road-remix-10218169/ |access-date=2022-11-04 |website=Metro |language=en}}</ref>\n| birth_place       = [[Golconda, Illinois]], U.S.<ref name=\"Lindsay-2019\"/>\n| genre             = {{flatlist|\n* [[Country music|Country]]\n* [[rockabilly]]\n* [[oldies]]\n* [[Christmas music|Christmas]]\n}}\n| occupation        = {{hlist|Singer|voice actor}}\n| years_active      = 2017\u2013present\n| label             = {{flatlist|\n* [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]]\n* [[Big Loud]]\n}}\n| website           = {{URL|https://masonramsey.com}}\n}}\n\n'''Mason Ramsey''' (born November 16, 2006)<ref name=\"Lindsay-2019\"/> is an American singer. In March 2018, after gaining Internet fame from a [[viral video]] of him [[yodeling]] \"[[Lovesick Blues]]\" by [[Hank Williams]] at a [[Walmart]], Ramsey was signed to [[Big Loud]].\n\n==Career==\nIn March 2018, 11-year-old<ref name=\"Rolling Stone\">{{Cite magazine|last=Bernstein|first=Jonathan|date=2018-08-27|title=Mason Ramsey: Inside the Curious Fame of 'Lil Hank Williams'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-country/mason-ramsey-inside-the-curious-fame-of-lil-hank-williams-716053/|access-date=2020-12-30|magazine=Rolling Stone|language=en-US}}</ref> Mason Ramsey, from [[Golconda, Illinois]], was seen on camera singing \"[[Lovesick Blues]]\" in a [[Walmart]] store in [[Harrisburg, Illinois]]. Within a few days, videos of his performance collectively garnered over 25 million views and he became a viral sensation and [[internet meme]].<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=http://time.com/5225039/walmart-yodeling-boy-video-goes-viral/|title=The Internet Has Fallen Hard For This 10-Year-Old Boy Yodeling at Walmart|magazine=Time|access-date=April 5, 2018}}</ref> Ramsey's performance sparked new interest in [[Hank Williams]]' 70-year-old recording of the song and in March ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' reported that [[Spotify]]'s Viral 50 chart for the U.S. ranked Williams' \"Lovesick Blues\" at number three, and number four around the globe.\n\nAs a result of his newfound fame Ramsey made an appearance on ''[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]''. Saying that his dream was to appear on the [[Grand Ole Opry]] one day, DeGeneres surprised Ramsey by saying he had been booked for the following weekend.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Betts|first1=Stephen|title=How Yodeling Walmart Kid Gave New Life to Hank Williams' 'Lovesick Blues'|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/country/news/how-yodeling-walmart-kid-gave-new-life-to-lovesick-blues-w518952|website=RollingStone|date=April 10, 2018 |access-date=April 11, 2018}}</ref> On April 13, 2018, American DJ [[Whethan]] brought Ramsey out during his set at the 2018 [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival]] in Indio, California.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Alexander|first1=Bryan|title=Coachella 2018: Walmart yodeling kid Mason Ramsey wows music festival, Justin Bieber|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/life/entertainthis/2018/04/13/coachella-2018-walmart-yodel-kid-mason-ramsey-music-festival/516455002/|website=USA Today|access-date=April 14, 2018}}</ref> In late April, he signed a record deal with [[Atlantic Records]] and Nashville-based label [[Big Loud Records|Big Loud]].<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8393343/yodeling-boy-atlantic-records-big-loud-famous-single|title=Yodeling Boy Signs With Atlantic Records & Big Loud, Releases 'Famous': Listen|magazine=Billboard|access-date=April 28, 2018}}</ref> His debut single \"[[Famous (Mason Ramsey song)|Famous]]\" entered at number 62 on the US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]],<ref name=\"famous\">{{Cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/8455115/mason-ramsey-famous-country-charts-willie-nelson |title=Mason Ramsey, 11, Is Newly 'Famous' on Country Charts; Willie Nelson, 85, Still Is |last=Asker |first=Jim |date=May 8, 2018 |magazine=Billboard |access-date=May 8, 2018}}</ref> while the EP debuted in the top 10 of ''Billboard''{{'}}s Heatseekers Albums chart at number 7.<ref>{{cite magazine |title=Billboard Heatseekers Albums - Week of August 4th, 2018 |url=https://www.billboard.com/charts/heatseekers-albums/2018-08-04 |magazine=Billboard |access-date=August 8, 2018}}</ref> Ramsey performed iconic number 1 songs on the [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] chart's 60th anniversary; starting from the 1960s, he sang hit songs by [[Mariah Carey]], [[Billy Joel]], [[Paul McCartney]], [[Stevie Wonder]], [[Celine Dion]], [[The Monkees]], [[The Jackson 5]], [[Whitney Houston]], [[Beyonc\u00e9]], and [[Adele]].<ref>{{Cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/country/8468423/mason-ramsey-sings-beyonce-whitney-houston-video|title=Watch Mason Ramsey Sing Beyonc\u00e9, Whitney Houston & More No. 1s Through the Decades|magazine=Billboard|access-date=August 15, 2018}}</ref> On June 8, 2018, he released his cover of \"Lovesick Blues\". On June 29, 2018, he released \"Jambalaya (On the Bayou)\" and \"The Way I See It\". On July 20, 2018, he released his debut extended play (EP), ''Famous''. He was featured on [[Lil Nas X]]'s third \"[[Old Town Road]]\" remix along with [[Billy Ray Cyrus]] and [[Young Thug]],<ref>{{Cite news |last=Frank |first=Allegra |date=July 12, 2019 |title=Lil Nas X's latest \"Old Town Road\" remix features Young Thug and the Walmart yodeling kid |work=[[Vox (website)|Vox]] |url=https://www.vox.com/culture/2019/7/12/20691728/old-town-road-remix-lil-nas-x-young-thug-mason-ramsey-walmart-yodeling-kid |access-date=July 23, 2023}}</ref> and joined Lil Nas X on stage to perform it at the [[62nd Annual Grammy Awards]].<ref>{{Cite news |last=Martinelli |first=Marissa |date=January 26, 2020 |title=Lil Nas X Performed Every \"Old Town Road\" Remix at Once at the Grammys |work=[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]] |url=https://slate.com/culture/2020/01/grammys-lil-nas-x-old-town-road-performance-video.html |access-date=July 23, 2023}}</ref> In the same year, he was recognized as one of the YMCA's 15 under 15 for his contributions to country music.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Representative Mike Zalewski Receives the 2018 Legislative Hero Award |url=https://www.ymcachicago.org/greater-lagrange/news-events/representative-mike-zalewski-receives-the-2018-legislative-hero-award |access-date=2023-04-30 |website=YMCA |language=en}}</ref>\n\nAfter a hiatus since 2019, he did a [[Burger King]] commercial in which he yodels about cow-based [[methane emissions]] in 2020.<ref name=king>{{Cite magazine|title=Mason Ramsey Yodels About Reducing Cow-Based Methane Emissions in New Burger King Commercial|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/9418491/mason-ramsey-burger-king-commercial|last=Mamo|first=Heran|date=July 15, 2020|access-date=September 21, 2021|magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=G-P7VceH9F8|title=Burger King - Cow's Menu ft. Mason Ramsey|date=July 14, 2020 |via=YouTube}}</ref> Ramsey said he now plays basketball under the name Mason Blake, and that he plays on an outside court with friends.<ref>{{Cite AV media|url=https://open.spotify.com/episode/2tcSagxcoItQC9FDdMWCCp?si=tU9WNTP5TAW1WEnOIYsVDA&nd=1|title=Episode 111 YouBetchERN Radio W/ Mason Ramsey and Earnest|date=2021-03-24}}</ref>\n\nIn 2022, Ramsey's song \"Before I Knew It\" from his 2019 EP ''Twang'' gained popularity on [[TikTok]] after he used it in several videos updating followers about his life, revealing he now works at [[Subway (restaurant)|Subway]].<ref name=\"Music Mayhem\">{{cite web|url=https://musicmayhemmagazine.com/yodel-boy-mason-ramsey-went-viral-in-walmart-before-i-knew-it-he-was-working-at-subway/|title='Yodel Boy' Mason Ramsey Went Viral In Walmart In 2018 & \"Before I Knew It\" He Was Working At Subway in 2022|website=Music Mayhem|last=Palsa|first=Nicole|date=January 29, 2022|access-date=February 4, 2022}}</ref>\n\nOn June 30, 2023, Ramsey released the single \"Reasons to Come Home\", his first new music release in nearly four years.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Nicholson |first=Jessica |date=2023-06-05 |title=Mason Ramsey Pays Tribute to His Hometown With Upcoming Single, 'Reasons to Come Home' |url=https://www.billboard.com/music/country/mason-ramsey-single-reasons-to-come-home-1235345672/ |access-date=2023-06-29 |magazine=Billboard |language=en-US}}</ref> On August 4, 2023, Ramsey released his second single this year, \"She Got It Outta Me\", a month after the release of the first single.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Chua |first=Jeremy |date=2023-08-04 |title=Mason Ramsey Gets an Unexpected Surprise in 'She Got It Outta Me' [Listen] |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/mason-ramsey-she-got-it-outta-me/ |access-date=2023-08-04 |website=Taste of Country |language=en-US}}</ref> On September 15, 2023, Ramsey released another song, \"Next Right Thing\", which, along with the previous two tracks released this year, included on his new EP.<ref>{{Cite magazine |last=Lorge |first=Melinda |date=2023-09-16 |title=LISTEN: Mason Ramsey Wants To Do The \"Next Right Thing\" In Optimistic New Single |url=https://musicmayhemmagazine.com/listen-mason-ramsey-wants-to-do-the-next-right-thing-in-optimistic-new-single/ |access-date=2023-09-16 |website=Music Mayhem Magazine |language=en-US}}</ref> All three songs released in 2023, along with two new songs \"All I Wanna Be\" and \"Falls Into Place\" were released as part of the new EP ''Falls Into Place'' on October 20, 2023, after four years from the release of the previous EP.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Rooten |first=Melanie |date=2023-10-19 |title=Mason Ramsey's New EP, 'Falls Into Place,' Showcases His Musical Evolution: 'This Is Not the Same Mason' |url=https://countrynow.com/mason-ramseys-new-ep-falls-into-place-showcases-his-musical-evolution-this-is-not-the-same-mason/ |access-date=2023-10-19 |website=Country Now |language=en-US}}</ref> On November 10, 2023, Mason Ramsey released a Christmas country cover of the song \"[[Run Rudolph Run]]\".<ref>{{Cite web |last=Smith |first=Emily |date=2023-12-13 |title=Where is Mason Ramsey, the kid who went viral for yodelling in a Walmart now? |url=https://thetab.com/uk/2023/12/13/where-is-mason-ramsey-the-kid-who-went-viral-for-yodelling-in-a-walmart-now-341907 |access-date=2023-12-13 |website=The Tab |language=en-UK}}</ref>\n\nOn January 26, 2024, Ramsey released a new single, \"Here All Day\", followed by \"Blue Over You\" released on February 23, 2024.<ref>{{Cite web |last=White |first=Logan |date=2024-01-26 |title=Mason Ramsey Releases Heartfelt New Single \"Here All Day\" |url=https://substreammagazine.com/2024/01/mason-ramsey-releases-heartfelt-new-single-here-all-day/ |access-date=2024-01-26 |website=Substream Magazine |language=en-UK}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web |last=Danforth |first=Libby |date=2024-02-28 |title=Mason Ramsey Is All Grown Up and Dropping Heartbreak Ballads \u2014 Hear 'Blue Over You' |url=https://tasteofcountry.com/mason-ramsey-blue-over-you/ |access-date=2024-02-28 |website=Taste of Country |language=en-US}}</ref> On April 26, 2024, Ramsey released his next single, \"Something You Can Hold\".<ref>{{cite web |title=Something You Can Hold - Single by Mason Ramsey |url=https://music.apple.com/kz/album/something-you-can-hold-single/1741414382 |website=[[Apple Music]] |access-date=2024-04-26}}</ref> On June 20, 2024, Ramsey performed with [[Lana Del Rey]] at [[Fenway Park]] during her stadium tour debut. They performed a duet of \"Blue Over You\".<ref>{{Cite web |last= Chelosky |first= Danielle | date=2024-06-20|title= Watch Lana Del Rey Bring Out Quavo, Mason Ramsey, & Stephen Sanchez At Nearly Rained-Out Fenway Concert|url=https://www.stereogum.com/2268970/watch-lana-del-rey-bring-out-quavo-and-mason-ramsey-fka-yodel-boy-at-nearly-rained-out-fenway-concert/news/ |access-date=2024-06-21}}</ref> On June 28, 2024, Ramsey released two singles: \"All The Way To Memphis\" and \"How Do I Know If I'm In Love\".<ref>{{Cite web |last=Iahn |first=Buddy |date=2024-06-21 |title=MASON RAMSEY ANNOUNCES TWO NEW SINGLES |url=https://themusicuniverse.com/mason-ramsey-announces-two-new-singles/ |access-date=2024-06-21 |website=themusicuniverse.com |language=en-US}}</ref> Ramsey released his debut album ''I'll See You In My Dreams'' on September 20, 2024.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://holler.country/news/breaking/exclusive-mason-ramsey-premieres-cowboys-always-come-home-ahead-of-debut-album-i-ll-see-you-in-my-dreams/ |title=Mason Ramsey Premieres 'Cowboys Always Come Home' Ahead Of Debut Album I\u2019ll See You In My Dream |date=2024-09-19 |website=Holler |last=Owen |first=Jof}}</ref>\n\n==Discography==\n===Studio albums===\n{| class=\"wikitable plainrowheaders\"\n|-\n!
